quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: A. E. Seaman Mineral Museum
data.listingDescription: Discover the mineral heritage of the Keweenaw Peninsula.

images.altText: Red brick building with green metal front. A sign above the door reads A.E. Seaman Mineral Museum
images.title: A. E. Seaman Mineral Museum
images.caption: The A. E. Seaman Mineral Museum in Houghton, MI.

data.bodyText:
One of North America’s premier mineral museums, the A. E. Seaman Mineral Museum is nationally and internationally recognized by mineral collectors and connoisseurs. Featuring the largest public exhibit and finest collection of minerals from the Great Lakes region and the world’s best collection of Michigan minerals. This museum’s exhibits feature the rich colors of nature's masterpieces. While visitors marvel, they learn about minerals through informative displays and discover how minerals are important in your life. 

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The A.E. Seaman Mineral Museum is located north east of the intersection of Garnet Street and Sharon Ave in Houghton, Michigan. The main entrance is located on the north of the building, with a concrete walkway leading from the parking lot. The building is built from red concrete bricks, but the main entrance face is made from green metal. The roof of the building is flat, but the main entrance face has a dramatic swoop to its roofline. A set of metal and glass double doors allow people into the building at the entrance. There are also two four-panel windows on the north side of the building. The museum has an extensive collection of rocks from the Keweenaw and all over the world inside. To the west of the museum outside is a rock garden and picknick space for guests.

data.title: Agassiz Field

images.altText: Spring picture of open field area with small football pitch.
images.title: Agassiz Field
images.caption: Agassiz Field in Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText: Agassiz Field sits on land that was once the northern boundary of Agassiz Park. This park is named after Alexander Emmanuel Rodolphe Agassiz who was born in Switzerland in 1835 and emigrated to the United States with his family in 1846. Agassiz played a major role in the founding and operation of the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company. The field was recently renovated, including new playing surface and track. It is now home to the Calumet Copper Kings.
data.audioDescription: Agassiz field is located just north of Agassiz park on the eastern side of downtown Calumet. The field runs east/west and has a track around it with a football ground in the center.

data.title: Adventure Mining Company
data.listingDescription: Visit the Adventure Mine.

images.altText: wooden building with a false-front and prominent mortared poor-rock wall and stairs to the entrance
images.title: Adventure Mining Company
images.caption: The Adventure Mining Company in Greenland, MI.

data.bodyText:
Visit Adventure Mine and experience rappelling down a mine shaft, underground drilling and blasting workshops, or an easy guided walking tour. We accommodate all ages, skill levels, and interests. Our 60- and 90-minute guided tours and 3-hour rappel tours are offered daily. The 6-hour underground tours and workshops are offered with advanced reservation.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: Adventure Mine is located at the corner of Adventure and Depot Streets in Greenland Michigan. The main office, gift and ticket shop is located on the south side of Depot St. The main office is built from wood with a corrugated metal roof and false front. A poor-rock wall surrounds the building with stairs leading up to it from the parking lot and picnic tables flanking the sides of the main office. Mine tours of different lengths and difficulties are offered to guests who wish to go underground and explore the mine. An extensive trail system extends from the parking lot to the south of the main building which allows visitors to see the ruins left from the mining period.

data.title: 311 6th St.

images.altText: Single story red brick building with flat roof.
images.title: 311 6th St.
images.caption: 311 6th St. in downtown Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText:
The lots last used by the Keweenaw Home Nursing and Hospice building were formerly occupied by several historic buildings. By 1893, the lots were occupied by 5 houses, a stable, and a saloon. In 1897, there were 8 houses on these lots. By 1908, there were four houses on lot 8, the south lot, and a four-story apartment building with two commercial storefronts had been constructed on the front half of lot 7, the north lot. This impressive building was probably built by the Vertin family. In 1908, the storefronts on lot 7 were occupied by a grocery store, and a tailor.     
By 1917, there were four storefronts; two were occupied by barbers, one by a tailor, and one by a print shop. By 1928, Lot 8 was occupied by a one-story garage known as Taxi Pete’s. The lots now used for parking were once home to other historic buildings as well, including Gately-Wiggins Company’s three-story department store, the Swedish ME Church and parsonage, and two other houses. Taxi Pete’s, the Vertin apartment building, and the Gately-Wiggins store were all destroyed in a catastrophic fire in 1972. The church and parsonage were later demolished.
data.audioDescription: The block at 311 Sixth street in downtown Calumet has a varied history. It was originally an area for housing but between 1917 and 1942 changed to feature a single-story garage. Today a single-story red brick building stands with flat roof. Three square windows can be seen directly next to each other on the north end of the eastern side.

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Warehouse #1
data.listingDescription: The C&H Mining Company used this building as a centralized location for mining supplies.

images.altText: Fall scene with the sun illuminating a long 2 story red brick warehouse
images.title: Calumet & Hecla Warehouse #1
images.caption: Calumet & Hecla Warehouse #1

data.bodyText: Calumet and Hecla Mining Company built Warehouse No. 1 (1893-1894) to consolidate its scattered supplies and to centralize ordering and distribution. The Warehouse was designed by Calumet and Hecla’s architectural staff. It stands 2½ stories tall. This industrial building has an exterior of red brick masonry with a basalt rock foundation. Built alongside a railroad spur to facilitate deliveries, the interior of the warehouse features parallel rows of storage bays along a central passage. Inside, you would have found various items necessary for mining - from helmets and boots, to spare nuts and bolts.
data.audioDescription: A two-story, red brick warehouse building stands in the former C&H Industrial Core. The long building once had railroad tracks running along the west side. Tall windows on the first and second floors, run the length of the building and provided much needed natural light to this large industrial building. Two side entrances include a loading dock platform at the middle of the east side of the building with a small gabled entrance just to the north of the loading dock. A large gravel parking lot to the east of the building extends to Mine Street with trees and grass to the south of the parking lot. The pitched roof is a gray asphalt roof with a dormer at the center of the length of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Warehouse #2
data.listingDescription: Larger equipment, unloaded inside on rails, was stored here.

images.altText: Green single story corrugated building with windows on top and a double door main entrance.
images.title: Warehouse #2
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla warehouse #2.

data.bodyText: The Calumet and Hecla Mining Company Number 2 Warehouse is a single-story wood-frame building with green-painted metal cladding. While rare now, cladding a building in corrugated metal was common for buildings serving industrial purposes in Calumet’s history. Rail tracks ran through this warehouse so that large items could be unloaded or loaded directly to large bays inside. The tracks have been removed, but the large doors allowing trains to pass through the building remain. The building is now privately owned. Please respect private property.
data.audioDescription: Warehouse Number 2 is located on the north side of Red Jacket Road between the intersections of 4th Street and Mine Street. This long rectangular building extends perpendicular to Red Jacket Road. Its main entrance is just of the road and consists of two large wooden doors with a person door located just to the right of it. Paneled windows almost completely coat the building near the roofline around its entirety. The warehouse is made from green-colored corrugated metal. The foundation is dark-grey poor rock with evident light-grey grout lines. The building has a very shallow pitched roof with corrugated metal on top.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet Mine #3 Shaft Collar

images.altText: Brick arch rising out of concrete with woodchips and playground equipment in the background.
images.title: Calumet #3 Shaft Collar
images.caption: The Calumet #3 shaft collar in Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText: Calumet #3 shaft was once a part of the Calumet Mine, a precursor to the mighty Calumet & Hecla Mining Company. Copper Country mine shafts all served identical purposes - a worker's entrance and exit to the underground and a centralized location for hoisting copper rock from below.
data.audioDescription: The Calumet & Hecla Number 3 Shaft Collar is located just behind the Calumet, Laurium, and Keweenaw school buildings in downtown Calumet. The collar is a brick arch rising out of the concrete in the school’s playground.

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Powder House
data.listingDescription: Heavily fortified to limit damage in case of accident, explosives were stored inside.

images.altText: A poor rock building , a heavy metal door with brick arch above, and a corrugated metal roof.
images.title: C&H Powderhouse
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Powderhouse

data.bodyText: The Calumet and Hecla powder house is one of the oldest of the companies surviving above ground structures. Thick poor-rock walls were chosen to limit damage in case of accidental explosion. A thick banded iron door compliments the walls as an additional safety measure. The explosives miners used to blast away rock were stored here to keep them stable and prevent accidents. The building is situated away from high traffic areas of the mine property.
data.audioDescription: The Powderhouse is located north of Red Jacket Road and west of Calumet Ave, behind the Calumet schools. The building is made from rough dark-grey poor rock with squared blocks on the corners and evident light-grey grout lines. The entrance to the building is located on the west side. It consists of a heavy iron door with three long strap hinges and a brick arch above. Three locks can be seen on the left side of the door holding it shut. The roofline slopes up from each corner to a central peak. The roof is covered in silver-colored corrugated metal.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Round House
data.listingDescription: C&H built the Round House to support and maintain the most expansive mining company railroad.

images.altText: Winter scene of dark-grey single story poor-rock building with dark-grey brick addition.
images.title: C&H Round House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Mining Company Round House.

data.bodyText: The Calumet & Hecla Mining Company built a massive railroad operation to transport copper ore from the mine to stamp mills and smelters, and to import other materials. The roundhouse was built to service this Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad. At the time most steam locomotives could only drive in one direction, so a turntable was needed for them to turn around. The circular house built around the table was often used for storage and servicing of railroad equipment. Altered for modern use, the rounded sides of the building indicate its former use beside a central turntable. The building is now privately owned. Please respect private property.
data.audioDescription: The Roundhouse is located at the corner of Depot Street and Mine Street. This building was originally constructed of dark-grey poor-rock but has received numerous additions and updates. This side of the building can be seen standing at the intersection of Depot and Mine Streets. The right side, that one closest to Depot Street still has the original poor-rock wall visible that also maintains the curve of the original structure. The Depot Street face has a small white metal garage door. Around the corner to the Mine street side has a single person door with a brick arch above it along with two old windows with brick arches above now covered with white siding. To the left of these windows is a large rectangular aluminum structure that propped above the ground. To the left of this is a dark-grey brick addition with a loading dock door and single person door. Finally, to the left of the addition is another portion of the original poor-rock building. This section has a single person entrance with a brick arch above it. This door sits above the ground surface and is accessed by metal stairs. There are also three loading dock doors in this section of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Dry House
data.listingDescription: Workers changed closes before and after their underground shifts.

images.altText: Winter scene of single-story poor-rock building with evident light-grey mortar lines.
images.title: C&H Dryhouse
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Dry House.

data.bodyText: A dry house is a building where miners would hang their soiled, wet clothes to dry for their next shift. After their underground shifts, miners changed soiled clothes for clean ones before heading home. This dry house was built by the Calumet and Hecla company for workers in the number 2 and 4 shafts. The building stands one story tall and the walls are made from poor-rock, a biproduct of mining operations.
data.audioDescription: The Dryhouse is located Northeast of Red Jacket Road between the Colosseum and the Drill Shop. The building is constructed from poor-rock with wide light-grey mortar lines. Large, squared blocks of poor-rock were used in the corners. The building is one story tall with a shallow-pitched roof toped with silver-colored corrugated metal. The eastern side of the building has two entrances with light-grey brick arches over top. Four panel windows with similar arches sit above these doors, one of which is covered in rusty-blue corrugated metal. Small windows with arches and covered in the same metal flank the entrances. On the south side of the building numerous small window holes have been covered in rusting corrugated metal.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Machine Shop
data.listingDescription: Large mining equipment was repaired here.

images.altText: Summer scene of two-story poor-rock and brick building
images.title: C&H Machine shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Mining Company Machine Shop.

data.bodyText: This machine shop is a 20-foot-tall single-story building made of poor-rock, a leftover from mining processes. Large wooden trusses can be seen inside the building to help support the walls and roof. It stands as one of the companies largest above ground structures at the mine. Large equipment including mine skips and tram cars were repaired here. The building is now privately owned. Please respect private property.
data.audioDescription: This two-story machine shop is located alrong Mine Street at the intersection of Depot Street. The first story and end walls are built from shaped poor rock. Brick trimm caps the tops of the numerous windows. The upper story sides are short and span the space betweeen the top and lower roof. This upper wall also has many windows with the sides being built of tin and stone. The roof is made from tin and houses six ventelation stacks. All of the old windows except those on the second story have been replaced with tin and boards. The numerous doors for the building vary in size from a single person to vehicle and are painted red. Green ivy can be seen growing up the Mine Street face of the building.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Copper Country Firefighters History Museum
data.listingDescription: The history of firefighting in the Copper Country.

images.altText: Summer scene of two-story sandstone building with tall triangular pergola and triangular false front
images.title: Copper Country Firefighter Museum
images.caption: The Copper Country Firefighters History Museum in Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Copper Country Firefighters History Museum stand in the historic Red Jacket Fire station, built in 1898. The building stands two stories tall and is made of red Jacobsville sandstone. The tower used for drying fire hoses still can be seen on its southeast corner. The fire hall was in use until the 1960s when it moved to its new location. From 1960 to 1991 the building was used for storage. A group of volunteers came together to create the non-profit Firefighter’s Museum. The museum features displays dedicated to the history of fire fighting in Michigan’s Copper Country. The historic fire trucks appeal to people of all ages.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Copper Country Firefighters History Museum is located on the west side of 6th street between Oak and Elm streets. This ornate two-story building is made from red Jacobsville sandstone. The front faces east toward 6th street. Five arches span the length of the main story. The three in the center are wide enough to accommodate trucks and have green-painted garage doors. The two other arches, which flank the middle three, are much narrower. On the second story there are six tall rectangular windows with arched tops. The roof is flat, but the eastern front has three different types of arches. The northern one is a smooth peak. The central and widest one is a stepped peak. The southern arch extends as part of a tower above the roofline and was used for drying fire hoses. The museum was built in 1898 and served as a fire hall until 1964. In 1974 the building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places and now servers as a museum.

data.title: Carnegie Museum
data.listingDescription: The historic Carnegie Museum.

images.altText: brick building with red sandstone foundation. A sign above the main entrance reads: public library.
images.title: Carnegie Museum
images.caption: The Carnegie Museum in Houghton, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Carnegie Museum of the Keweenaw shows changing exhibits about the area’s cultural and natural history. The building was original constructed after Andrew Carnegie provided a $15,000 grant in 1909 for the construction of a public library. The building is a two-story red-brick structure with red Jacobsville foundation. The museum was founded in 2006 when the public library moved to its new location. The upper story houses the museum’s exhibits while the downstairs space has been renovated for public events.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Carnegie Museum is located at the corner of Huron Street and East Montezuma Avenue in downtown Houghton. The foundation of this one-story building is made from large red Jacobsville sandstone bricks. The main story is made from red brick with Greek revival pillars on either side of the main entrance which is in the center of the building. A false arch roof stands over the main entrance while the rest of the building has a flat roof. A large block of sandstone mounted over the entrance doors reads “public library.” Two large rectangular windows with red sandstone slabs on top flank the main entrance. Ornate dark red stone trim highlights the space between the top of the windows and the roofline. An iron fence runs along the edge of the path leading from the street to the main entrance. The Carnegie Museum building started its life as a public library in 1910. In 2006 the library moved, and the building was repurposed as a museum by the fall of that year. In 2012 the museum underwent an extensive renovation and preservation project to ensure its life for the future. The first-floor features exhibits on local history, while the basement is finished and used for events.

data.title: Chassell Heritage Center
data.listingDescription: Explore Chassell's history.

images.altText: Summer scene of yellow three-story wooden building with red sandstone foundation.
images.title: Chassell Heritage Center
images.caption: The Chassell Heritage Center in Chassell, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Chassell Heritage Center stands in the old schoolhouse built after a fire destroyed 2 of the 3 school buildings in Chassell. The new schoolhouse was funded Charles Worcester, owner of Chassell’s lumber mill which provided employment to most of its residents. The school remained in operation until 1992 and has been maintained by the Chassell Historical Organization since. The building stands three stories with an elevated foundation made from red Jacobsville sandstone. Exhibits follow Chassell’s history from a logging camp to today. A collection of vintage clothing provides a glimpse into people’s lives.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Chassell Heritage Center is located at the corner of 2nd and Hancock Streets in Chassell. The building originally was a school built in 1917 and served as such until 1992 and has been used by the Chassell Historical Organization sense. The heritage center has a prominent red Jacobsville sandstone foundation with numerous six panel windows on its south facing front. The building has clapboard siding painted yellow with numerous rectangular windows with green trim. The windows have six panes on top and a single on the bottom. The main entrance, located in the center of the building, has a single pitched roof which extends to the south and is supported by two Greek revival columns. In the middle of the building is an ornate cupola with eight sides. Inside the heritage center there are exhibits about local history on the main floor and auditorium space for public meetings and events on the second floor.

data.title: Calumet Schools
data.listingDescription: A company built and run school system were another aspect of the far-reaching C&H control.

images.altText: Winter scene of red brick school building with many windows and brick encased digital sign in front.
images.title: Calumet Schools
images.caption: Calumet, Laurium and Keweenaw Public Schools

data.bodyText: The first school in the Calumet area was built in 1867 and was a one-room building. By 1875 the population had drastically expanded, so the Calumet and Hecla company built the original Washington School at a cost of $15,000. The support of C&H allowed the company influence over curriculum and activities. However, with constantly increasing population by 1915 the original school was not capable of supporting local students. The original building was moved, and additions were made to support this larger body of students. The latest additions to the school included the purchase of land behind the school and building of new elementary school which opened in 1998. Today these schools and their later additions continue to serve the Calumet-Laurium-Keweenaw School District.
data.audioDescription: The Calumet schools are located at the corner of Calumet and School streets on the Northwest side of Calumet St. The schools are built in a U shape with three buildings built at three different times connecting to each other. All three buildings are constructed from red brick. The building on the west as seen from Calumet St. is the oldest and darkest red in color. It is four stories tall with the first story partially underground. Two main entrances for this building are in the center of the U, or the east side of this building. The south side facing the road has a zigzagging metal fire escape leading to the top floor. White Greek-revival concrete runs as trim for the roof. The northern most building is the newest and runs parallel to Calumet St. Three large, paneled windows sit in the middle of this building with two entrances flanking them to the right and left. The eastern building has a gothic style of architecture that stands in contrast to the other buildings. One entrance is located on the face near the road and three are in the center of the U. Windows run around the building. A digital sign encased in brick and a flagpole are located in the very center of the U next to Calumet St.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Bath House
data.listingDescription: Bathhouses were one of many amenities provided by Copper Country Mining Companies.

images.altText: Fall scene of a two-story brick and poor-rock building
images.title: C&H Bath House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla bath house.

data.bodyText: To serve a growing workforce the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company constructed a stand-alone bath house with an indoor pool for workers and their families in 1910/11. It cost the company $45,000 in construction costs! The building stans one story tall and is made of red brick. It has an elevated foundation made of poor-rock. Women and children could use the house for free, men paid three cents, and boys two-and-one-half cents. One worker was employed just to check bathers for contagious disease! The building is now privately owned. Please respect private property.
data.audioDescription: The bath house is a two-story brick building with poor-rock mosaic half story foundation located at the corner of Depot St. and Calumet Ave. The building is a T shape which long face runs along Calumet Ave, and center extends back along Depot St. The mine poor-rock in the foundation has been neatly cut and ranges from grey to green and red in color. Numerous large six-panel windows ring the building in the foundation. Two sets of stairs with red metal railings lead up to the two entrances; originally designed for male and female sides of the bath house. A large set of three windows sit between the main entrances, and one set on the outside of the entrances. Six-panel windows surround the rest of the building. Decorative brick and a white stone center have been placed above the upper six-panel windows. Currently the building has a black asphalt shingle roof with red metal trim.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: California Riding and Hiking Trail at Geology Tour Road

images.altText: An information board next to a trailhead with a short wooden fence.
images.title: Geology Tour Road Backcountry Board
images.caption: The California Riding and Hiking Trail intersection with Geology Tour Road

tags: "National Park" "Joshua Tree" "California Riding and Hiking Trail" Trail
data.bodyText:
Revealing Queen Valley 

Look around—this open valley was formed because the valley floor you are driving across is eroding faster than the surrounding mountains. The valley floor is softer than the metamorphic rock that makes up the surrounding mountains, so it weathers and erodes faster.  

Building a Foundation  

Making Gneiss: Around 20 miles (32 km) below the surface extremely high temperatures and intense pressure caused the minerals in sediments that were once on the ocean floor to rearrange and form a new, durable metamorphic rock called gneiss (pronounced “nice”).  

Intrusive Granites: Oceanic crust began sliding beneath the crust of the continent, in a process called subduction. Intense heat and pressure, along with water and gases from the oceanic crust, melted rock beneath the continental crust. This melted rock was more buoyant than the crust around it, and it began to rise—though it never quite made it to the surface. 

Exploration Area  

Take a hike east or west from here on the California Riding and Hiking Trail. Carry water with you. 

Glossary  

Subduction: The process in which the edge of one continental plate is pushed under another plate into the earth’s mantle.  

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: A natural process by which water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Metamorphic: Metamorphic rocks form when high temperatures and pressure act on a rock to alter its physical and chemical properties (metamorphism means 'to change form'). This process occurs deep under the Earth’s surface. Uplift and erosion bring metamorphic rock to the earth’s surface.
data.audioDescription: A small dirt pullout located on the east side of the dirt Geology Tour Road. There is enough space for approximately four to five vehicles at this pullout. A backcountry board with backpacking rules and safety information is located at the start of the trailhead. The trailhead also has a short wooden fence. The surrounding area is scattered with desert plants including Joshua trees, creosote bush, and Mojave yuccas.

data.title: Delaware Mine

images.altText: Fall scene of a single-story wooden building with autumnal trees in the background.
images.title: Delaware Mine
images.caption: The Delaware Mine in Keweenaw County.

data.bodyText:
The Delaware Mine was in operation for forty years but never turned a profit for its investors. Despite this, it stands today as a prime example of mining in the Keweenaw during the 1800s. At Delaware Mine, visitors can take a self-guided tour of one of the oldest underground copper mines on the Keweenaw Peninsula. Above ground trails lead around the ruins of the two original mine buildings, equipment displays, antique engines, and trains.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Delaware Mine is located just off Delaware Road in Delaware. The main building and gift shop is located adjacent to the parking lot. It is a single-story building with a primarily flat roof that peaks in the center. The front has a large roofed-over entrance area with impromptu seating near the entrance to the building. The building itself is made from round timbers at the base and wooden panels above it. Four windows, tow on each side of the entrance door located in the middle of the building, are framed with red shutters. The main door and the window trim are all white while the building is painted a deep brown. The Delaware mine operated for forty years but never made a profit for its investors. Despite its commercial failure, it is a prime example of what mines in the Keweenaw looked like during the 1800s. Visitors can explore the ruins still left above ground and venture below ground to view one of the shafts and the technology used to extract ore.

data.title: Dougherty Wagon
data.listingDescription: This Dougherty wagon has connections to three separate national park sites which makes it a unique artifact to the story of Grant-Kohrs Ranch, the National Park Service and the nation’s transportation history.

images.altText: This Dougherty wagon is located on display inside of thoroughbred barn at Grant-Kohrs Ranch.
images.title: Dougherty Wagon
images.caption: The historic Dougherty Wagon on display inside of the Grant-Kohrs Ranch thoroughbred barn.

data.bodyText:
This Dougherty wagon was purchased by Johnny Grant in 1862. It was shipped up the Missouri River from St Louis, Missouri, to Fort Benton, Montana aboard the steamboat Emilie. When Grant sold the ranch to Conrad Kohrs in 1866, this wagon was included in the purchase and its believed that it was used to carry the newly-wed Conrad and Augusta Kohrs, from Fort Benton to their new home here on the ranch.

The Dougherty wagon was originally designed as a passenger wagon. They typically featured side doors, two or three rows of seats, and canvas or leather sides that could be rolled up with ease.  Another feature was that the seats could be folded down to create a flat surface or bed and were often converted into use as an ambulance, especially by the Army during the Civil War. Following the battle of the Big Hole (Big Hole National Battlefield) on the morning of August 9, 1877, this wagon was called into such service and was temporarily used as an ambulance to transport wounded soldiers from the battlefield to St. Joseph’s Hospital in Deer Lodge.

These wagons were also constructed to travel long distances and were desirable for their comfort and safety when riding over rough terrain. The Kohrs family used this wagon for a seven-week tour of Yellowstone National Park in 1883.

There are only a handful of Dougherty wagons known to exist, which makes this wagon a unique artifact of the National Park Service and the nation’s transportation history.
data.audioDescription: This Dougherty wagon is located on display inside of thoroughbred barn at Grant-Kohrs Ranch. It is on display on the right side of the building near the back. There is a wooden beam running, vertically in front of the wagon that separates visitors from the historic item. The Dougherty wagon is roughly seven feet tall and, seven feet long and seven feet wide. The passenger box is roughly 4 feet tall, 4 feet wide, and four feet long. There are a pair of small wooden side doors, located in the middle of the wagon for passengers to climb in and out and two rows of seats. front seating area and a back-seating area. The insides are covered in patterned orange canvas, with red circular dots. The seats are covered in a black canvas. The seats fold down to create a flat surface. There are four, circular wagon wheels located on each corner of the wagon. The wheels are made of wood and painted black. The entire wagon, except for the canvas lining the inside is painted black.

data.title: Drill Shop
data.listingDescription: Sharp drill steels were essential for hard rock mining.

images.altText: Winter scene of a poor-rock two story building with metal roofing.
images.title: C&H Drill Shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Drill Shop.

data.bodyText: The Calumet and Hecla drill shop is an L shaped building. The east/west wing stands two stories tall with the second floor only covering the middle half of the building. The north/south wing stands one story tall and has a flat roof. The entire building is made from poor-rock, a leftover from mining. The windows and doors are toped with red brick, a common theme in the Copper Country. Here, skilled workers manufactured and repaired mining drill steels. These steels were rods with tips, often in the shape of a star, sharpened on their ends. They were used to drill cylindrical holes in the rock wall where an explosive charge would be placed.
data.audioDescription: The Drill Shop is located Northeast of Red Jacket Road behind the Colosseum. The building sits in a reverse L shape with the longer end running northeast/southwest and is one story tall. The shorter side of the building is two stories tall. The building is made from dark grey poor-rock with a large amount of silver-colored corrugated metal on the short side’s roof and sides of the second story. The original entrance to the short side of the building sits on its left-hand side with two arch-topped windows on either side of it, now covered in silver-colored corrugated metal. To the right of this set of windows and door is the current main entrance for this side. It juts out from the building and is made from silvered-corrugated metal. It has a single door and one window with a steep-pitched roof. Just to the right of this entrance is an old square entrance that is now bricked over. On the top of the second story facing the road, a sign reads “Copper Country Curling Club.” The longer side of the building has numerous arch-topped windows, some of which are bricked over.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Fort Wilkins Historic State Park
data.listingDescription: Visit Fort Wilkins Historic State Park.

images.altText: Summer scene of red sandstone building surrounded by trees and a sidewalk leading to the entrance.
images.title: Fort Wilkins Historic State Park
images.caption: Fort Wilkins Historic State Park in Copper Harbor, MI.

data.bodyText:
The U.S. Army built Fort Wilkins in 1844 to keep the peace in Michigan’s Copper Country. However, this was not necessary and by 1870 the army permanently abandoned the facility. The fort was made into a Michigan state park in 1923. It now serves as an example of mid-19th century army life on the northern frontier. Today 19 buildings survive including 12 original structures from 1844. The park also includes copper mine sites, museum exhibits, lighthouses, and outdoor interpretive trails.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: Fort Wilkins Historic State Park is located on US 41 in Copper Harbor. The giftshop pictured here is located just west of the oval-shaped parking lot. It is a single-story building made from wood and prominent red and white Jacobsville sandstone corner foundation and wall accents. The rest of the walls are made from wood painted green. Paneled windows with white wooden trim are present on the left side of the building. The entrance to the building is in its center which functions as a covered walkway. The giftshop is located on the left and restrooms are on the right. The building has a gable roof with black asphalt shingles. The rest of the expansive park is located west of the giftshop. Visitors can explore recreated buildings from the park and learn about the life of the people that lived there over the years. Reenactors are present in select buildings throughout the park to teach visitors about the history of the fort and provide a more real-life window into the past.

data.title: Gandy Dancer's Shack
data.listingDescription: Home to the railroad's "gandy dancers."

images.altText: Winter scene of a small poor-rock building with metal roof and brick chimney remnant.
images.title: C&H Railroad Shack
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Railroad Shack.

data.bodyText: The Calumet and Hecla railroad, or Gandy Dancer’s shack is located on the far western end of the industrial core. The building is a single story made from poor-rock, a leftover from mining processes. Gandy dancers were men who rode the rails to care for the tracks. The shack was built for them to keep their tools in.
data.audioDescription: The Railroad Shack is located between 6th Street Extension and the Captain’s Office. The building is constructed of poor-rock with clear light grey mortar lines between the stones. Larger dark grey poor-rock stones were squared to form the corners of the building. A small section of rock has been replaced by red brick on the front of the building. The hole where an old door or window stood on the front and 6th Street side have been replaced with corrugated metal. The roof is also made from corrugated metal which slopes up from each corner to form a single short ridge line at the top. Near the front of the building is a remnant of a brick chimney poking through the roof.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Hanka Homestead Museum
data.listingDescription: The Hanka Homestead was occupied by members of the Hanka family, Finnish immigrants, from 1896 until 1966. Herman Hanka settled here with his family after he was injured in a copper mining accident. The farm was originally homesteaded at a time of mass immigration from Finland to the United States. The homestead is relatively intact and unaltered from its appearance in the 1920s. This museum is an official partner of Keweenaw National Historical Park.

images.altText: Summer scene of historic wooden home and out-buildings surrounded by trees.
images.title: Hanka Homestead
images.caption: Hanka Homestead Museum in Pelkie, MI.

data.bodyText:
Herman Hanka settled this homestead with his family after he was injured in a copper mining accident in 1896. The homestead sits on 40 acers of land with 8 standing buildings. This indoor/outdoor museum allows visitors to learn about the life of immigrant families and their experience living in the Copper Country. Volunteers, when available, provide guided tours of this 1920s-era Finnish Farm. A self-guided brochure is also available. Call ahead for large groups.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Hanka Homestead is located at the end of Hanka road northwest of Baraga. When visitors enter through the main gate at the north end of the homestead, they are greeted by two beautiful small cabins. From there they walk through the old fields of the homestead which house neatly lined old farming equipment and a few cars. The main homestead is set on a hilly green landscape with numerous trees of varying species in the background. The original house still stands along with numerous outbuildings including hay and animal barns, sauna, woodshed, and underground root cellar. The house is a two-story building with two dormer windows. The entrance to the home is located on the right-hand side of the building. Two four panel windows can also be seen on the first floor. All the windows have white wooden trim around them. The homestead was farmed by the Hanka family from the 1890s until the 1960s. It has been restored to reflect the 1920s and provide a view into the experiences of Finnish immigrants to the Upper Peninsula.

data.title: Hecla Fire Station
data.listingDescription: Fire protection was one of many services provided by C&H.

images.altText: Winter scene of two-story red metal building with one window on top and 5 garage doors.
images.title: Hecla Fire Station
images.caption: The Hecla Fire Station

data.bodyText: The Calumet & Hecla company provided services to the public such as police and fire protection which communities do today. This fire station served mines and company neighborhoods to the south. Originally there was a second Calumet fire station north of Red Jacket Road. The building is now home to the Calumet Township Fire Department. Please do not park in the fire lane.
data.audioDescription: The Calumet Township Fire and Rescue building is located where Rockhouse road intersects Mine Street; the building sits on the north side of Mine Street. This building’s design suggests that it is composed of two buildings joined. The entire building is covered in red corrugated metal. The structure on the left, or west side, is a tall single-story garage with three doors in the front. A shallow pitched roof slopes from the center of the buildings to the west. The right, east side, building is a two-story building with a shallow pitched roof sloping west and east. Two garage doors form the front of the building with person entrances on the eastern face for both the first and second story. A large four panel window sits in the center of the main building just above the garage doors. A large sign on the front of the main building says, “Calumet Twp. Fire & Rescue.”

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Gatehouse at Thomas Edison's Laboratory Complex

images.altText: Exterior of painted red shingled house with green trim a slate roof and a small staircase to a door.
images.title: Edison Lab Gatehouse
images.caption: Thomas Edison's Laboratory Complex Gatehouse

data.bodyText: Thomas Edison's Laboratory Gatehouse

data.title: Gear House
data.listingDescription: Delivering motive power to the surface and underground.

images.altText: Winter scene of a black poor-rock building with complex and steep-sloped roof.
images.title: C&H Gear House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Gear House.

data.bodyText: The Calumet and Hecla gear house is located in the center of the industrial core. This two-story building with steep gabled roof is made from poor-rock, a biproduct of mining operations. The original machinery in the gear house helped deliver mechanical power to the mine and surface facilities as well.
data.audioDescription: The gearhouse is located north and west of the Red Jacket Road and Mine Street intersection. This building’s complicated shape speaks to the intersection of three separate buildings, or one that was extended from. The gearhouse is built from black poor-rock with squared corners and thick grey/brown mortar lines. The central structure is square in shape with a roofline that extends at a sharp angle to a central peak. The main entrance to the building is on the northeast side of the building. A double door entrance is framed by two large arch-topped windows. One extension to the building is an L shape on the southwest corner of the main structure. This extension is made of the same poor-rock as the main building and its roof slants to a peak that runs in the same L shape as the structure. The other extension is a shallow L that extends from the north face of the building. One side of the L extends a short way from the main structure and runs parallel to it, the other longer end of the L extends away from the building near the northeast corner of the main structure. This extension is also constructed of black poor-rock.

data.title: Finnish American Heritage Center
data.listingDescription: Learn about Finnish culture and heritage.

images.altText: Winter scene of concrete building with blue metal roof. Front lettering reads Finlandia University.
images.title: Finnish American Heritage Center
images.caption: The Finnish American Heritage Center in Hancock, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Finnish American Heritage Center is located on the campus of Finlandia University. Finlandia University was founded as Suomi College in 1896 and is now the only remaining North American institution of higher learning that was founded by Finnish Americans. The heritage center was opened in 1990. It houses the Finnish American Historical Archive and Museum, a theater, an art gallery, and the offices of The Finnish American Reporter. Regular performances and art exhibits highlight Finnish culture.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Finnish American Heritage Center is located at the intersection of Quincy and Mesnard streets. The building is made from light grey colored concrete. The building’s unique roofline features steep slope that runs all the way to the top on the left side, but on the right side of the building there is a sheer drop from the central portion of the building before the side roof slants to the edge. The roof is made from blue metal. The main entrance to the building is located on the left side and has a set of concrete steps and a wheelchair access ramp leading to it. The center of the building has a series of rectangular windows that highlight the three stories of the building. The right side of the building has smaller rectangular windows. The center was opened in 1990 and has since become a community focal point and regularly has visits from scholars around the world.

data.title: Copper Range Historical Museum
data.listingDescription: Explore the history of South Range and its nearby communities.

images.title: Copper Range Historical Museum
images.caption: The Copper Range Historical Museum in South Range, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Copper Range Historical Museum is located in the former Merchants and Miners Bank building. The building stands two stories tall and is made from red-brick and has corners of smoothed red Jacobsville sandstone. Artifact-rich displays depict people’s lives and work experiences in the range towns of southern Houghton County during the copper mining era.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Copper Range Historical Museum is located at the intersection of Trimountain and Champion avenues in South Range. This one-and-one-half story building is made from light red brick with red sandstone blocks highlighting the corners. The main entrance is located on the south side of the building. There is a metal sign above the door that reads “Copper Range Historical Museum.” A large glass window with glass brick on either side sits to the left of the main entrance. The east and west sides of the building have numerous rectangular windows on the first floor and short rectangular windows on the upper half story. Ornate red trim surrounds the top of the building and leads on the north and south faces of the building up to the peak. The roof has asphalt shingles and is gently sloped. There is a brick chimney in the back on the building extending up from the roof. The building prior to housing the museum the building housed the Miners and Merchants Bank. Today there are exhibits focusing on local history.

data.title: Coppertown Mining Museum
data.listingDescription: Once home to the C&H pattern shop.

images.altText: Yellow brick single story building with sign on the front saying Coppertown USA Mining Museum.
images.title: Coppertown Mining museum
images.caption: Coppertown Mining Museum in Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText:
Housed in the former Calumet & Hecla pattern making shop. Skilled artisans worked in this building to design patterns which were used for casting metal components. The building is made of yellow brick and stands one story tall with a shallow-pitched gabled roof. The museum features exhibits on the former copper mining giant’s operations.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Coppertown USA Mining Museum is located at the corner of Red Jacket Road and Armory Drive in Calumet. This single-story building is made from yellow brick with a trim of red flashing under the roof. The roof is made from silver-colored corrugated metal. The front entrance is located on the west side of the building. Two red doors lead to the building on the left of the entrance are two pairs of large rectangular windows with red trim. On the right of the entrance is a large sign saying “the Coppertown USA Mining Museum.” The building originally functioned as a Pattern Shop. Now there are exhibits on geological and mining history.

data.title: Electric Substation
data.listingDescription: An evolving company embraced a relatively new technology.

images.altText: Yellow brick building with square windows, a garage door and many external electric connection bars.
images.title: C&H Electric Substation
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Electric Substation.

data.bodyText: The Calumet & Hecla electric substation is a two-story building made from yellow brick. While the building is no longer used for power, remnants of its old purpose can be seen in the circular ceramic insulators passing through the brick. Calumet & Hecla embraced new technologies like electricity in its effort to become more efficient and profitable. As a result, its mines and many residents of the neighboring villages had early access to electrical power.
data.audioDescription: The Electric Sub Station is located north-northeast of the intersection of Red Jacket Road and Mine Street. This two s tory building is constructed of yellow brick and has a pitched roof. The front of the building faces east-southeast. A large garage door sits in the center with two rectangular window openings now covered with wood on either side. A rectangular paned window is also located in the center of the front face on the second floor. Two long metal beams run just above the garage door that would have been connected to electrical wires in the past. The north-northeast face of the building has three large paned rectangular windows and a single door. There are two short metal beams above the door that would have held wire connections in the past. There is a small roof extension above these beams.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Geology Tour Road Intersection

images.altText: An information board next to a dirt parking spot and a dirt road.
images.title: Information Board at Geology Tour Road
images.caption: First Pullout on Geology Tour Road

data.bodyText:
Geology Motor Tour 

Down this dirt road, the story of Joshua Tree National Park's unique geologic history is written in the stones. A series of five roadside stops will help reveal the story these rocks have to tell. Follow this tour to travel the road and learn about the forces that have shaped Joshua Tree in the past and continue to do so today. Directions to each stop along the tour will include the mileage between stops; consider resetting your trip odometer to help you find the next stop. 

Road Info  

• Distance—18 miles (29 km) round trip; 5 miles (8 km) one way to Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 

• 4-wheel drive is recommended; high clearance necessary beyond Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k 

• Expect soft sand and steep grades  

• Off-road driving is prohibited  

• Drive slowly and carefully; speed limit 25 mph (40 km/hour)  

• One-way travel after  Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k  

Safety Info  

• No food, water, gas, cell phone service or restrooms beyond this point  

• Use caution near abandoned mines — stay out and stay alive  

• Leave wildlife, plants, rocks, and artifacts undisturbed  

• Overnight camping on road is prohibited; backcountry camping by permit only  

• Campfires are prohibited
data.audioDescription: The Geology Tour Road intersects with Park Boulevard in an open expanse of desert. The area is lightly sprinkled with plants including Joshua trees, cactus, and creosote bush. Geology Tour Road is a dirt road and near the intersection is a small dirt parking area that some would consider to be a large pullout. There is an informational sign and a vault toilet.

data.title: Keweenaw County Historical Society

images.altText: Summer scene of white and red buildings with a lighthouse and lake in the background.
images.title: Keweenaw County Historical Society
images.caption: Keweenaw County Historical Society in Eagle Harbor, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Keweenaw County Historical Society was established in 1981 by a group of volunteers. The historical society maintains 11 sites in Keweenaw County. The Eagle Harbor Lighthouse Museum Complex includes the lighthouse, Maritime, Keweenaw History, and Commercial Fishing Museums. Other sites include Rathbone School, Lifesaving Station, Central Mine, Phoenix Church,Bammert Blacksmith Shop, Eagle River Museum, and the Historic School at Gay.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Eagle Harbor Lighthouse is located in Eagle Harbor on Lighthouse Road. The lighthouse is made from red brick, half of which is painted white. The lighthouse is attached to a one-and-a-half story red brick building. The building has a steep pitched roof which flares at the end. The windows are rectangular with white trim. The museum at the site is located adjacent to the lighthouse in a two-story building with wide white wooden siding. A brick chimney can be seen rising from the shallow pitched roof. The lighthouse was built in 1871 to help ships into the harbor. The museum houses exhibits on local maritime history. Large objects including an anchor and old steel buoy are spaced around the exterior.

data.title: Keweenaw Heritage Center

images.altText: Summer scene of main entrance to red sandstone church.
images.title: Keweenaw Heritage Center
images.caption: Keweenaw Heritage Center in Calumet, MI

data.bodyText:
Located at the head of downtown Calumet's commercial district, the Keweenaw Heritage Center, formerly St. Anne's Church, is a pivotal structure of the Calumet Downtown National Historic Landmark District. The St. Anne’s Church was built before 1900, replacing a wooden French Church. The new church was made from red Jacobsville sandstone which reaches 32 feet to the eves and has a gabled roof. The front spire on the northeast corner of the building extends 140 feet into the air. The church was purchased by the Charter Township of Calumet in 1994 and adapted to server as an education and cultural center.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Keweenaw Heritage Center at St. Anne’s Catholic Church is located at the corner of Scott and 5th streets in Calumet. The building is made from red Jacobsville sandstone. The main building has a very tall single story with a steep gabled roof. The main entrance sits on the north end of the building and has three adjacent entrances. The center entrance is slightly larger than the one on either side. Steep and slightly curved arching roofs extend out from the main building to cover the entrance. Four tall windows with arched tops are evenly spaced on the front face above the entrance. One window is located directly above each of the side entrances and two are evenly spaced above the main entrance. On the left side of the front a tall steeple rises above the roofline. The sides of the building have tall arch-toped windows like those in the front evenly spaced throughout. The heritage center works to preserve and interpret the vast amount of heritage in the Copper Country through exhibits, educational programs, and work to preserve buildings in the historic district of Calumet.

data.title: Keweenaw History Center
data.listingDescription: Formerly the public library, the building also housed shower facilities in the basement.

images.altText: two-story stone and brick building along sidewalk
images.title: Keweenaw History Center
images.caption: The Keweenaw History Center in winter.

data.bodyText: This combination library and bathhouse was built by the Calumet & Hecla Mining Company in 1898 for the Village of Calumet. The building is two stories tall with a gabled roof. It is made from many-colored poor rock with brick accents on the corners and around the windows. The popular bath house soon had its own facility, and this became the Calumet & Hecla Public Library. At the library, the company offered a careful selection of educational materials in many languages as an effort to educate and assimilate their workforce into American society. Now known as the Keweenaw History Center, it houses NPS Lake Superior Collection Management Center staff, historical artifacts, and archives. Research appointments are available.
data.audioDescription: Two-story mosaic patterned stone building located on the corner of Red Jacket Road and Mine Street. Red brick adds a decorative detail around windows, on the corners of the building, and as a visual break between the basement and first floor level. Tall, double hung windows run the length of the second floor and are just below the decorative roof cornice trim. At the center of the first floor is an entrance to the building that has 7 stairs leading to two black wooden doors with windows. The entrance has a gabled roof the width of the stairs and peaks just below the second story windows. Two double hung windows are on either side of the gabled entrance on the first floor. A sidewalk along Red Jacket Road is fifteen feet from the building with an additional sidewalk going to the stairs and entrance. Just a few feet from the sidewalk is a wooden sign that says Keweenaw History Center in white routed letters. This lettered sign hangs from a tall wooden post with a wooden arm that extends from the main post.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Laurium Manor Mansion

images.altText: Fall scene of large three-story white house with grand entrance, wrapping porch, and brick chimney.
images.title: Laurium Manor Mansion
images.caption: Laurium Manor Mansion in Laurium, MI.

data.bodyText:
Thomas Hoatson Jr., owner of the Calumet & Arizona Mining Company, built this 45-room, 13,000 square foot home in 1908 using the finest and rarest building materials available. Mansion tours are self-guided and takes 30-60 minutes. Printed guide and smartphone audio tours are included. Lodging at the mansion is available year-round.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Laurium Manor is located on Tamarack street between 3rd and 4th streets. This three-story mansion has white painted wooden siding. The front entrance has prominent red sandstone steps leading up from the sidewalk. Red sandstone blocks are also used as retaining walls in the yard and garden around the building. The front entrance is covered by a two-story gable roof with four ornate Romanesque pillars supporting it as it extends from the house. A porch sits on the second story of this entrance extension. Porches also wrap around the ground floor of the house and have covered roofs supported by smaller Romanesque columns like those in the front. A round set of windows on the front corner of the right side of the building harkens to Queen Anne style construction. The third floor has two dormer windows facing the road and a brick chimney rising from the back of the building. The manor was built by Thomas H and Cornelia Hoatson in 1908. Now the 13,000 square foot house serves as a bed and breakfast and also hosts tours so visitors can see the grand style some of Calumet’s residents used to live in.

data.title: Locomotive Shop
data.listingDescription: Railroad maintenance was essential to keeping C&H running smoothly.

images.altText: Winter scene of wood and poor-rock building with a large entrance, now boarded and sealed.
images.title: C&H Locomotive Shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Locomotive Shop.

data.bodyText: The locomotive shop was built in 1883 out of poor-rock with brick accents around some of the windows and doors. Here workers repaired company locomotives and rail stock here prior to the construction of the round house in 1888. It then served as a blacksmith and general repair shop for the Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad. Later it also served as a pipe and pole shop, and a machine shop.
data.audioDescription: The Locomotive shop is located just behind, northwest, of the Machine Shop. This single-story building has tall walls made of poor-rock and wood. From this perspective two gabled entrances for trains can be seen on the right and left of the building. Four smaller doors are between the two train entrances. On the left-hand face of the building three windows are visible with arched brick trim on top. In the center of the roof is a large ventilation stack. The Locomotive Shop is now surrounded by young birch trees, and most of the rail tracks surrounding it have been removed.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Malapai Hill Viewpoint Parking Area
data.listingDescription: The parking area to access views of Malapai Hill.

images.altText: A sun setting behind a dark-colored hill
images.title: Malapai Hill Viewpoint
images.caption: The view of Malapai Hill near its parking area.

data.bodyText:
Construction by Destruction 

Unlike the incremental changes caused by weathering and erosion, some geologic process have changed Joshua Tree’s landscape in short, violent events.  

Malapai Hill 

Volcanic Origins: Standing tall above Queen Valley to the west, the hard, black basalt of Malapai Hill weathers and erodes slowly. This volcano is much younger than the surrounding monzogranite and likely formed within the past 15 million years. 

Blue Cut Fault 

Ancient Earnt Valley: Located to the south southwest, there has not been an earthquake on this fault in the last 8,000 years, but it is still active and could generate a moderate earthquake. One of many fault lines in the park, the Blue Cut Fault extends for over 50 miles (80 km) through the heart of the park. Earthquakes on this fault have resulted in over four miles of offset over the last few million years, with the north side of the fault moving west and the south side moving to the east and the uplift of the Hexie Mountains along the northern edge of Pleasant Valley.

Exploration Area  

Explore the ancient remnants of a volcano with desert views —hike to the top of Malapai Hill or around its base. Do not attempt during high temperatures. 

Glossary 

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Basalt: A dark fine-grained volcanic (i.e. igneous) rock.  

Uplift: The elevation of the Earth’s crust. Usually referring to tectonic uplift caused by slowly moving plates that cause earthquakes and changes to the earth’s surface.
data.audioDescription: A small, dirt pullout on the west side of the road. The view to the west reveals a dark-colored hill. To the south is a gently sloping plain towards mountains. To the north and east lie a few small rock formations. Desert vegetation surrounds the pullout.

data.title: Man Engine House
data.listingDescription: An early innovation in getting employees in and out of the mine.

images.altText: Winter scene of brick building with a ramp leading to its front door.
images.title: C&H Man engine House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Man Engine House

data.bodyText: Originally this building housed a steam powered man engine. The building is a single-story brick structure with poor-rock foundation and hipped roof. This machine used a series of platforms that raised and lowered workers in and out of the mine, making for safer and faster entry than long ladders. Workers would step from one side of the moving platform to another as they paused. The building was later converted into a small warehouse and is now privately owned.
data.audioDescription: The Man Engine House is located northwest of Mine Street between the intersections of Depot St and Red Jacket Rd. This building has a mortared poor-rock foundation with the rest being constructed of red brick. The center of the building has a large set of two doors with an arched paneled window above. The doors and trim of the window are painted in a grey/brown color. On either side of the door are a paneled window set with an arched top. Either side of the building has three equally spaced paneled windows with an arched top. The roofline runs from each corner of the building to a single point at the top.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Mine Captain's Office
data.listingDescription: Only the most experienced would ever be mine captains.

images.altText: Winter scene of a dark brown poor-rock building with wide light grey mortar lines.
images.title: C&H Mine Captain's Office
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Mine Captains Office.

data.bodyText: The mine captain’s office is located on the western end of Calumet’s industrial core. It is a single-story structure made from poor-rock with brick accents above the windows and doors. The first floor is raised above a partially submerged basement and the attic space has been finished. Mine captains, often skilled immigrants from distant mining regions, oversaw the daily mining operations underground. They frequently wore white for identification, marking their status compared to the dirty work of mining.
data.audioDescription: The Captain’s Office is in the V between Mine Street and the 6th Street Extension. This building is made from poor-rock. Large rocks have been cut for the corners of the building with smaller rocks used in the rest of the walls. Large light grey mortar lines can be seen between the rocks. The main entrance is in center of the front face of the building, raised off the ground and accessed by a set of metal stairs. A brick arch is located above the door and the line of a roof that once sat above the entrance can be seen in the wall. Two windows flank the entrance with brick arches above them. Two pane storm windows sit on the outside while the inside window is made of smaller panes. There is also a smaller window constructed in the same way above the door. Smaller windows are also located below the windows flanking the door at ground level. The sides of the buildings have two windows with brick arches and smaller ground-level windows as well. A square brick chimney can be seen coming out of the center of the roof.

data.title: Mineral Range Railroad Depot

images.altText: Two story brick building with hipped metal roof.
images.title: Mineral Range Railroad Depot
images.caption: The Mineral Range railroad depot in Calumet, MI.

data.bodyText: Though vacant and quiet now, this railroad station once connected Red Jacket to faraway cities like Chicago and Milwaukee. Tears of joy and the chatter of various languages filled the air at this bustling entry point for the thousands of immigrants to the Copper Country. When the trains unloaded, family members might be reunited after months or sometimes years of separation. This station was originally made of wood but was updated to the current brick building between 1908 and 1917.
data.audioDescription: The Mineral Range Depot is located at the intersection of Ninth and Oak streets in downtown Calumet. The original depot was a single-story wooden structure with a hipped roof. A one-and-one-half story entrance was built on the south side of the depot. Between 1908 and 1917 the depot was re-built to a three-section brick building with a hipped roof and a wooden awning running around its entire perimeter. The central section is two stories tall with an office located on the western side. Two sets of double doors are located on the eastern face of this section with two rectangular windows between them. Rectangular double-pane windows are on the eastern and western faces of the second story. The southern section is a single-story with rectangular windows ringing it and a door located on this section’s southern face. The northern section was used as a baggage room and had rectangular double-pane windows ringing it. A brick chimney can be found in the center of the roof located between the central and northern building sections.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Miner's Memorial House
data.listingDescription: Many Quincy employees called this place home through the years.

images.altText: A park ranger speaks to a group of kids in front of a company house.
images.title: Miner's Memorial Company House
images.caption: A park ranger talks about company housing.

data.bodyText: The Copper Country has always been a remote location. To attract workers companies routinely built houses for their workers. This saltbox style home, built by the neighboring Pewabic Mining Company around 1870, had many occupants over the years. One was the family of Joseph Martin, who lived here with his wife and nine children. They left soon after Joseph lost his life in a mining accident in 1921. The house has undergone extensive stabilization and preservation in recent years.
data.audioDescription: Brown, two-story wooden house sits in an open grassy area approximately 200 feet to the north of the Hoist House. Behind the house is a former cooling pond in the shape of a narrow rectangle. To the north is a cluster of trees but in all other directions, the house has views of the former Quincy Mining surface ruins and operations: hoist house, #2 shaft-rockhouse, and rail stock parked along a grassy field in front of the house.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Miscowaubik Club
data.listingDescription: This private club hosted many of the community elite.

images.altText: Winter scene of two-story house building with yellow wooden siding and a brick-based sign out front.
images.title: Miscowaubic Club
images.caption: The Miscowaubic Club.

data.bodyText: The Miscowaubik club was founded in 1903 and is named after a local Native American term for “Red Metal.” A former mine captain's house was turned into an exclusive social club frequented by the elite of the community and nation. Bowling, billiards, squash, and fine dining have been among the networking benefits available to members. The club has been active since 1903, hosting members of the Boston Brahmin and major industrialists.
data.audioDescription: The Miscowaubik Club is located on the northwest side of Calumet Ave between the intersections of Red Jacket Road and School Street. The front of the building that faces the road has a new main entrance that extends to the road from the main structure. A brick path leads from the sidewalk running along the road to the entrance. The portion of the main building closest to Calumet Ave is a single story with yellow wooden siding and seven two-panel windows. The main building sits in an L shape with the longer end running perpendicular to Calumet Ave. A detailed three-part window can be seen above the main entrance on the second story with an arch in the center of the three-paneled window. Brick chimneys can be seen on the northeast and northwest ends. The roof is covered in dark-grey asphalt shingles. The buildings foundation is a mix of blue-painted concrete and dark-grey poor rock with wide grout lines.
