data.title: Ontonagon County Historical Museum

images.altText: Summer scene of periwinkle single-story modern building with flat roof.
images.title: Ontonagon County Historical Museum
images.caption: Ontonagon County Historical Historical Museum in Ontonagon, MI

data.bodyText:
The Ontonagon Historical Society was founded by local residents in 1957. The museum features exhibits on area mining, logging, farming, marine, and social memorabilia. Tours are provided of the nearby lighthouse which is the westernmost of Michigan’s lighthouses.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Ontonagon Country Historical Society is located on River street between spar and Quartz streets in Ontonagon. The building is a single-story modern style painted periwinkle. It is built from concrete block and has wooden siding on the street side. The main entrance is located near the street and is a single pink door. Parking for the historical society is located directly next to the building. The museum hosts exhibits on maritime, copper mining, logging, and agriculture in the area. Visitors can also go on tours of the Ontonagon Harbor Lighthouse which is the westernmost lighthouse in Michigan and the oldest in the copper district.

data.title: Parade Grounds

images.altText: Black and white historic image of men with rifles walking on a grassy field with a church behind.
images.title: Calumet Parade Grounds
images.caption: The former Calumet parade grounds.

data.bodyText: For many years a grassy greensward behind Calumet’s armory, located north of Calumet Ave between Depot Street and Red Jacket Road, served as a parade ground. Today this space serves as an example of change over time. For generations, soldiers of the Calumet Light Guard and later National Guard and ROTC drilled here. Festivals were held on the grounds, and troops camped here during a major labor strike in 1913-14. Today, the National Guard remains in the Calumet area with a new Readiness Center located just north of town. Three of the buildings that used to stand on the parade ground: the armory, warehouse, and painting shop, have all been removed. Currently this space is being redeveloped by the Calumet Electronics Company.
data.audioDescription: Once an open grassy field, it now houses a two story addition to Calumet Electronics. The building is a concrete structure with minimal windows and sits about 25 feet from highway US41, with a parking lot just to the north.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Pattern Shop
data.listingDescription: Custom made wood patterns were fashioned by skilled woodworkers.

images.altText: Winter scene of yellow brick building with poor-rock foundation and red doors and windows.
images.title: C&H Pattern Shop
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Pattern Shop.

data.bodyText: Calumet & Hecla's location away from distant manufacturing centers required the company to be self-reliant. The pattern shop is located in the center of Calumet’s industrial core. The building is a large single-story structure made from yellow brick with a shallow-pitched gabled roof. Originally the building was divided in the center to house both a pattern workshop and warehouse. Here, skilled workers crafted patterns used in the foundry to cast needed parts or tools. The pattern shop is now home to Coppertown USA Mining Museum.
data.audioDescription: The Pattern Shop, which has been repurposed as the Coppertown USA Mining Museum, is located at the intersection of Red Jacket Road and Armory Drive. This large single-story building is constructed of yellow brick with a poor-rock foundation. There is a two-door entrance on the rear face of the building. To its left is a four-panel window comprised of six panes to each panel; the window framing is red. To the right of the entrance are four more windows of the same design. A large section of brick has been updated on the southwest side of the building and has a slightly redder color than the original brick. There is also a red double door entrance above the ground on this side which is accessed by metal stairs.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park

images.altText: brick and wood building with steep asphalt shingled roof. A sign reads Wilderness Visitor Center
images.title: Porcupine Mountains State Park
images.caption: Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park in Ontonagon, MI.

data.bodyText:
In addition to wild forests and lakeshores, Michigan’s largest state park has numerous historic copper mining sites. The 59,020-acre park offers summer and winter recreational pursuits and interpretive programs. The park hosts a 35,000-acre old-growth forest amounts its waterfalls, rivers, trails, campgrounds, and Lake Superior shoreline.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Porcupine Mountains Wilderness State Park is located southwest of Ontonagon and the visitor center is located on Headquarters road. The visitor center is a tall single-story building which has a triangular shape. It is made from wood with a brick facade on the lower half of the walls. The steeply pitched roof is has grey/brown asphalt shingles. The park was established in 1945 and consists of 60,000 acers. Visitors can experience over 90 miles of hiking trails, camping and lodging sites, old growth forest, and historic sites including a few marked copper mines.

data.title: Quincy 1882 Hoist House
data.listingDescription: As technology progressed, so did hoist houses for the #2 shaft at Quincy. The 1882 was the second of four.

images.altText: Stone building with 5 boarded windows and a metal pitched roof
images.title: Quincy 1882 Hoist House
images.caption: The 1882 #2 Hoist House.

data.bodyText: Built in 1882, this structure housed the second hoist for the #2 shaft. The building is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick details over the windows and door. Recent preservation includes the addition of a new roof, tuckpointing, and window coverings. Original dormers have been removed. In 1894 the company built a new hoist for the #2 just down the hill.
data.audioDescription: Located to the east of Shaft-rockhouse #2, the single story hoist house sits in the shadow of the tall rockhouse. Made of mine poor rock, the building has five windows on either side, a pitched roof, and is directly under tall metal supports that once held cables that traveled from the Hoist House to the shaft-rockhouse and then underground. On the north side of the engine house, a gravel road runs east to west and on the south side of the building is the open landscape of the former Quincy Mine with abandoned wooden rail cars, and foundational ruins to former surface operation buildings.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Houghton County Historical Museum

images.altText: Summer scene of sign:Houghton County Historical Museum with covered antique slays in the background.
images.title: Houghton County Historical Museum
images.caption: Houghton County Historical Museum in Lake Linden, MI.

data.bodyText:
The Houghton County Historical Museum is located at the former site of the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company stamp mills in Lake Linden. Explore this seven-building complex, which includes a museum containing artifacts and photographs spanning 100 years, one-room schoolhouse, log cabin, railroad depot, research center, and an operating Plymouth gas/electric train engine.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: The Houghton Country Historical Museum is located on the east side of US 26 between Hubbell and Lake Linden. There is a large sign at the entrance to the parking lot from the road which reads “Houghton Country Historical Museum.” The museum sits in the Calumet and Hecla’s stamp mill office. Here visitors can find three stories of exhibits about mining, logging, and life in Houghton country. Outside there are examples of sleighs used to transport goods and people that now sit under freestanding roofs. There is also a working Calumet and Hecla steam engine that is used to give tours and interpretation of the milling operation at the site.

data.title: Italian Hall Site
data.listingDescription: Now a memorial park, the site is a grim reminder of a terrible tragedy in 1913.

images.altText: A stone memorial with a reflection of the Italian Hall arch
images.title: Italian Hall Site
images.caption: The Italian Hall memorial.

data.bodyText: The Italian Hall site is located just north of Elm and Seventh streets in downtown Calumet. A total of three buildings had the name of Italian Hall and stood in this location. The first two were made of wood; the first was three stories tall and the second was two. During a party here on Christmas Eve 1913, a false cry of "fire" incited a panic that claimed the lives of over 70 people, many of those children. After the fire, a new two-story brick building was constructed. This building was razed in 1984 and a memorial park was created with the original stone archway repositioned in the center of the lot. Each year on December 24th, a memorial service is hosted at the site.
data.audioDescription: A tall red sandstone archway sits in the center of a mowed town lot. A brick pathway leads from the sidewalk through the arch to a 8 foot tall stone monument that has engraved in white letters, the name of each person who perished in the Italian Hall event. The sidewalk makes a circle where two stone benches allow for personal reflection. Near the sidewalk is a long wayside interpretive sign that provides a brief overview of the Italian Hall event.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Keweenaw NHP Headquarters
data.listingDescription: Multiple additions over the years signify the growth of Calumet & Hecla Mining.

images.altText: Large l-shaped two-story stone building on street corner
images.title: Keweenaw NHP Headquarters
images.caption: Keweenaw NHP Headquarters

data.bodyText: The Calumet & Hecla Mining Company General Offices serve as the current headquarters for Keweenaw National Historical Park. The 1887 building was designed by Boston-based architects Shaw & Hunnewell. It was constructed of mosaic-like poor rock and field stone with brick trim. Mining operations were directed from here and the offices housed engineers, draftsman, and accountants. Miners or family members would wait inside the attached shed to collect their wages. Many in the community are more familiar with the building as the offices of Drs. Gilbert and Baron from the late seventies until the early 1990s. The National Park Service has occupied the building since 1993, serving as the headquarters for Keweenaw National Historical Park. An interior rehabilitation project was completed in 2008, while masons maintain the exterior.
data.audioDescription: The stone mosaic pattern and red brick building façade of the former C&H Mining Company headquarters is set apart from other buildings in the area. Located west of Highway 41 and north of Red Jacket Road, the two-story, L-shaped building is prominently located between the former C&H Industrial Core and managers homes that line either side of Highway 41 to the north. Directly across the paved drive to the west is a large three story home that was once the C&H Mine manager's summer house. Red brick adds a decorative detail on building corners, around windows, and three feet from the roof's edge. Tall windows with wooden panes delineate offices within the building and add to the buildings grandeur. Mowed grass surrounds the building between the sidewalk and the mosaic rock foundation. The L-shaped building has a small green, one story addition to the north that is made of metal wainscoting.

passportStampImages.altText: an orange passport stamp on white paper for Keweenaw NHP Calumet, MI
passportStampImages.title: Kewenaw passport stamp

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Pattern Storage Warehouse
data.listingDescription: Thousands of patterns were made over C&H's lifetime.

images.altText: Winter scene of poor-rock two story building with red sandstone blocks on the building’s corners.
images.title: C&H Pattern Storage Warehouse
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Pattern Storage Warehouse.

data.bodyText: The pattern storage warehouse served as a giant repository for the over 30,000 patterns that Calumet & Hecla used with “green” sand to cast machine parts and tools. The building is a two-story structure made of poor-rock, red and white Jacobsville sandstone blocks on the corners, and brick trim above the windows and doors. A single-story dry house, a location for miners to hang their wet and dirty clothes after the shift, was attached to this building. You can compare a pattern warehouse to a 3D printer’s library of files.
data.audioDescription: The Pattern Storage Warehouse is located east of 6th Street and south of Armory Drive. The building is constructed from poor rock with clear light grey mortar lines. The corners of the buildings are made of large red and white striped sandstone blocks. The front of the building has a large two-door entrance with a brick arch above it. The wood of the doors has been weathered to a dark grey color. There are two sets of windows on either side of the entrance and are located above the door. Another window is located directly above the entrance door. Each window has a brick arch above it. To the left of the main entrance is a small single red door with a brick arch above it. The main portion of the building has a single pitch roof sloping from right to left. The other portion of the building is a single story, with its roof sloping from left to right, its left edge on the far-right wall of the main building. There is a single person entrance door painted in red in the center of the smaller section with a brick arch above it. Two windows flank this door with brick arches above them as well.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine Engine House
data.listingDescription: A company that owned its own railroad also need a building for maintenance and repairs.

images.altText: Rectangular stone building with a flat sloped roof and window openings along the side and four doors
images.title: Quincy Mine Engine House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine Engine House

data.bodyText: Built in 1889, the Quincy Engine House served as a maintenance garage for the Quincy & Torch Lake Railroad. What began with 2 bays, soon became 3, and ultimately 4, signifying Quincy's growth at the time. The engine house is a tall single-story structure made from poor-rock and has a shallow-sloped flat roof. Brick arch details can be seen above the windows. Recent preservation includes tuckpointing, a new roof, windows, and doors.
data.audioDescription: The Quincy Engine House is located at the southern end of the former Quincy Mining Company property. The stone masonry building has a small cluster of tall trees on the south side and an open area to the west. A set of train tracks lead to the center of the building where four tall wooden doors provided train locomotive access to the building. Constructed of mine poor rock, the long rectangular building has a flat roof that slopes from north to south with a series of tall boarded up window openings along the length of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine Man Engine Shaft
data.listingDescription: Man engines revolutionized how miners navigated to and from their work site.

images.altText: Rusted rail, pipes and fencing cover an old mining shaft that is surrounded by a grassy area.
images.title: Quincy Man Engine Shaft
images.caption: The Quincy Man Engine Shaft

data.bodyText: In early years, miners climbed ladders to and from their work sites underground. Being both grueling and dangerous, Quincy installed a man engine. This mechanical ladder system proved useful and efficient but was abandoned in the early 1890s due to the depth of Quincy. The shaft is now capped with a "bat-friendly" enclosure, one of two on the Quincy site.
data.audioDescription: A seemingly open landscape on the former Quincy Mining Company property reveals more than initially meets the eye. A former mine entrance is labeled Man Engine Shaft on A metal sign labeled Man Engine Shaft identifies the location of the former shaft entrance which is about 20 feet west of the sign. Today, grasses and flowers grow over mine rock rubble mounds on either side of the original entrance and a gravel path leads from the sign to the former entrance. The entrance is completely covered by a makeshift cage consisting of weathered brown steel bars and fencing attached to the bars. The flat cage top extends across the former entrance and then angles into the ground on the east side at an angle. The cage was constructed for viewing access into the former entrance while also allowing bats to leave the entrance as the former shaft serves as an important bat habitat. A small wood platform and fence allows for viewing into the cage and entrance. The man engine shaft entrance is within 20 feet of U.S. Highway 41 on the east side. Some poor rock is piled on the west side of the cage.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine Pay Office
data.listingDescription: The Quincy Mine Office is a prominent reminder of management's watchful eye over Quincy property.

images.altText: two-story stone building made of rust colored Jacobsville sandstone
images.title: Quincy Mine Pay Office
images.caption: The Quincy Pay Office in winter.

data.bodyText: Situated on the south end of Quincy Mine property, The Quincy Mine Pay Office is a prominent reminder of past corporate paternalism. Built of local Jacobsville sandstone with slate roof, this two-story structure replaced the previous office in 1897. Recent preservation efforts include new roofing, windows, and surrounding fence.
data.audioDescription: Located on the west side of Highway 41, the two-story former Quincy Mine Office is made of rust colored Jacobsville Sandstone. Set approximately 50 feet from the highway in an open lawn and behind a wooden picket fence that goes along a gravel driveway that is wide enough for cars to park on either side. The large building looks more like a house than an office building and has a columned entryway with six wide stairs leading to a a covered porch.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Oil House

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white Jacobsville sandstone building with steep corrugated metal roof.
images.title: Quincy Oil House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine Oil House.

data.bodyText: Now known as the oil house, this building was used to dispense carbide for miner's lamps. Carbide, when mixed with water, would emit a burnable gas. This would be the most advanced personal lighting ever in use at Quincy. This building is a single story made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone. Brick arch detail can be seen over the entrance door. Recent stabilization includes a new roof and tuckpointing, ensuring building stability.
data.audioDescription: The Oil house is located northeast of the Number Two Shaft Rock House. The Oil house is constructed from red and white Jacobsville sandstone blocks. It has a steep roof with silver-colored corrugated metal siding. A set of red-painted wooden doors mark the only entrance to this building located on its south side. The east and west faces have two small square ventilation holes now covered in red painted wood at the base of the structure. A earthen ramp can be seen leading to the main entrance of the building.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Smelter
data.listingDescription: Operating until 1971, the Quincy Smelter is the only remaining industrial site of its type left in the world.

images.altText: Boarded up industrial buildings made of stone and brick are within a chain link fenced in complex.
images.title: Quincy Mine Smelter
images.caption: The entrance to the Quincy smelter

data.bodyText: The Quincy Mining Company built the Quincy Smelting Works on the banks of the Portage Canal in 1898. Quincy constructed the smelter to refine and ship its own copper, as well as to accept custom work from neighboring mining operations. In 1978, the Historic American Engineering Record documented the smelter complex in its study of the Quincy Mining Company. Due to the integrity of the historic resources at the site, the National Park Service then included the complex in the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District, and ultimately within the boundaries of Keweenaw National Historical Park.
data.audioDescription: A chain link fence surrounds the former Quincy Smelter operation, set along the Portage Canal. The smelter is a complex of brick and stone buildings, old rail trellises, and hard packed gravel surfaces between and around each building. The complex is large with a recreational snowmobile/walking trail bordering the fence to the north and the Portage Canal to the south. Hardened, melted slag from the smelting process sits in a pile a few acres in size between Highway 26 and the recreational trail. Part of a trellis remains and extends from the smelter to the slag pile. Another trellis leads from the eastern end of the site into the top part of a two-story building. Below the trellis is a long mound of gray stamp sand particles and a cluster of birch trees that have taken hold and are growing among rusted smelter carts.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy #5 Boiler House

images.altText: Winter scene of yellow brick building with roof partially removed.
images.title: Quincy #5 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #5 Boiler House

data.bodyText: The neighboring "world's largest steam hoist" required a massive amount of steam to operate. In the #5 Boiler House, eight coal-fired boilers boiled water, producing this steam. The building is a tall single-story structure made from yellow brick. A shorter single-story addition with gable roof can be seen on the southwestern face of the boiler house. Steel trusses supported the roof and the walls were covered in plaster. In recent years, stabilization has occurred, preventing further building deterioration. Do not enter this building as ruins can be unstable.
data.audioDescription: The Number Five Boiler House is located just south of the 1894 Hoist House. The building orients northeast to southwest and had an uneven roof; the western side being lower than the eastern. The boiler house is constructed from yellow brick and only a smaller single-story addition on the southern face of the building still has the corrugated metal roof. The metal trusses that supported the main buildings roof are clearly visible. Windows on the western and southern faces of the building have been removed leaving only their wooden trim. A railroad grade and part remnants of tracks can be seen entering the northern face of the building.

data.title: Quincy #7 Boiler House

images.altText: winter scene of dark-grey and red/white striped Jacobsville sandstone building ruins.
images.title: Quincy #7 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #7 Boiler House.

data.bodyText: The #7 Boiler House supplied steam to power for equipment like steam hoisting engines. This building housed two groups of four boilers which were separated by brick partitions. Coal fired boilers boiled water, producing the necessary steam. The steam flowed through pipes to provide power to machines sometimes located far away from the boiler house. Decorative features on the #7 boiler building include red brick archways over the doors and windows along with Jacobsville Sandstone quoins or building corners. An air pump was housed in an attached addition on the western face of the building and a stone chimney also stood next to the building on this side.
data.audioDescription: The Number Seven Boiler House is located southwest of the Number Four Hoist House. The building runs northeast to southwest and had two stories; the roof is now missing. The lower story had tall red brick arch-topped windows and doors. The second story has numerous rectangular red brick topped windows. A large square entrance can be seen on the north side of the second story. The corners of the buildings are accentuated by large red and white stripped Jacobsville sandstone blocks. A square single-story addition can be seen on the southwestern corner of the building. Just to the north of this addition is a square chimney base made in the same style as the Boiler House.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white sandstone building with snow covered parking lot.
images.title: Quincy Mine
images.caption: The Quincy Mine in Hancock, MI

data.bodyText:
The Quincy mine was owned and operated by the Quincy Mining Company from 1864 to 1945 and was known as “Old Reliable.” The moniker came from the company regularly paying dividends to investors from 1868 until 1920. Portions of over a dozen buildings stand for visitors to see and experience. On a two-hour tour, visitors take a guided walk through the hoist house, ride a cog-rail tram, and enter the mine to learn about mining life. Shorter, surface-only tours are also available.

The Keweenaw Heritage Sites are official partners of Keweenaw National Historical Park, but are privately owned. Each site interprets and preserves an important aspect of the area's copper mining history and provides a unique visitor experience. Please contact individual sites for more information.
data.audioDescription: Quincy Mine is located just off US 41 north of Hancock. The welcome building and gift shop is a one-and-a-half story structure made from red and white Jacobsville sandstone that was the Supply Headquarters during the mine’s operation. The building now has a silver-colored corrugated metal roof. A wooden raised porch wraps around the western and southern sides of the building which sit adjacent to the parking lot. The entrances for the building have arched tops with brick accents. Visitors to the Quincy Mine which operated for 99 years as “old reliable” can explore numerous ruins, learn about the history of the mine, and take tours underground to see the shafts and some of the mining equipment used by the men who worked there.

data.title: Star Wars Rock Viewpoint and Climbing Access Trailhead

images.altText: A dirt road leads towards rocks, a desert valley, and mountains.
images.title: Star Wars Rock Pullout
images.caption: The view from the Star Wars Rock pullout.

data.bodyText:
Building Boulders  

The unique, sculpted granitic boulder piles seen throughout the park are the result of jointing, weathering, and erosion. 

  1. Magma cooled and solidified miles beneath the surface to form various types of granitic rocks including the monzogranite that is common in the park. 

  1. Cracks or fractures— called joints— formed while these rocks were still underground due to stress from geologic forces. 

  1. Groundwater entered the joints and began rounding out the edges and corner, and weathering the rock into smaller pieces. 

  1. Erosion carried away small particles of broken-down rock, exposing rounded boulders. 

Notches mark the height and give us insight into past soil levels. The notches form because water in the soils is slightly acidic, slowly dissolving the rock away. Tafoni are concave pits of varying size that form on the rock’s surface from wind erosion or from soil contact (similar to how notches form). 

Exploration Area 

Scramble among the roadside boulders. See their crystalline structure. Feel their surfaces. Discover unique contours. 

Glossary 

Magma: Pressure and heat below the earth’s surface melts rock into a molten or semi-molten fluid called magma. When magma cools, igneous rocks are formed.  

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Monzogranite: a specific kind of biotite-rich granite rock. The monzogranite here is light-colored and is commonly seen in the northern part of Joshua Tree National Park.  

Tafoni: Rhymes with macaroni. Tafoni is a natural process that results in the formation of rock cavities. Tafoni occurs when long exposure to moisture eats away at a rock face. Stop by Skull Rock and look at the eye sockets and nose to see large examples of tafoni.
data.audioDescription: A small dirt pullout along Geology Tour Road. To the west are light-colored, granitic rock piles, including one called Star Wars Rock. Desert vegetation surrounds the area. The pullout is small and can only fit a few vehicles.

data.title: Superior Boiler House
data.listingDescription: Boilers provided heat and powered steam engines.

images.altText: Winter scene of poor-rock and red sandstone building with a red brick smokestack in the foreground.
images.title: C & H Superior Boiler House
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Superior Boiler House.

data.bodyText: Beneath tall, billowing stacks, coal-fired boilers boiled water. Here, the mine produced steam to power a wide array of steam powered surface equipment. These included steam hoists, which raised copper from deep underground. The boiler house is a three-part structure. One is the red brick chimney. Next to it is a tall poor-rock building with a steep hipped-roof with a small brick chimney rising out of it. The third portion is a red and white Jacobsville sandstone building with a gabled roof.
data.audioDescription: The Superior Boiler House is located between Mine Street and Calumet Ave, south of Church Street. The boiler house consists of two distinct connected buildings. The main entrance, and tallest building is located at the south and is in the shape of a square. It is made from grey poor-rock. The main entrance to this building is on the south face with a large garage door on the left-hand side. The rest of that face has three arched and brick-topped windows. The roof of this end of the building slopes steeply to a central point. A brick chimney can also be seen rising out of the south face of the roof. On the east face of this building a tall brick smokestack rises from an attached brick extension. This stack is fluted for support and is a rare construction style in the Keweenaw. The other portion of the building which is in the shape of a rectangle running parallel with Mine Street extends to the north of the first portion of the building. The northern portion is made from red sandstone and has numerous small arched windows along its faces. The tops of the windows are made from brick. The roof of both buildings is made from rusting corrugated metal.

data.title: Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
data.listingDescription: Built by the American Bridge Company in 1908, the Quincy #2 Shaft rockhouse serves as a reminder of the Quincy legacy.

images.altText: A 140 foot industrial building (shafthouse) lit by the setting sun with dark cloudy skies behind.
images.title: Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse
images.caption: The Quincy #2 Shaft Rockhouse.

data.bodyText: A part of one of the Keweenaw’s most profitable and long-lasting copper mines, the No. 2 Shafthouse stands over the shaft where men would go underground to work and where copper-bearing rock was brought up from below. One of several mine shafts at the Quincy location, the #2 was the longest, extending over 9,000 feet along the angle and reaching an overall depth of 6,225 feet below the surface. Men mining on the 92nd level would have spent their entire 8-hour shift working more than a mile underground in 90-degree heat. Over time without use the shafthouse severely rusted, leading it to be resided in the mid-1980s - an early preservation effort by the Quincy Mine Hoist Association.
data.audioDescription: The prominent #2 shaft-rockhouse building is over 140 feet tall and can be seen for miles on top of Quincy Hill. The building is approximately 30 feet east of U.S. Highway 41 and has a large gravel parking lot to the north of the building. Visitors to the site park in this lot and can walk into the building's interior with the entrance located on the north side of the building. To the east, a tall metal pulley stand remains and was used to support the large cables that traveled from the hoist house into the shaft-rockhouse near the top of the building. At the base of this pulley stand, is a small rock masonry building. To the south of the shaft-rockhouse, are some abandoned wooden rail cars and beyond, an open landscape with stone foundations of former buildings. The building's height and unique shape are directly linked to the underground below. When positioned in the parking to the north and looking at the building, the roof angles down to the ground at a 50 degree angle. This same angle extends underground and is the angle by which skip cars and man engine cars traveled into the ground

data.title: Quincy #4 Boiler House

images.altText: Winter scene of collapsed poor-rock building with brick arch-topped windows.
images.title: Quincy #4 Boiler House
images.caption: The Quincy #4 Boiler House.

data.bodyText: The #4 Boiler House used its coal fired boilers to produce steam to power equipment such as hoisting engines. The boiler house was originally a two-story structure made from poor-rock with arched brick detailing above the windows and doors. Four boiler sets sat in brick surrounds inside the building. Two 18-foot tall stone chimneys sat next to the building, one on each of the northern and southern faces. Between 1888 and 1908 a single-story wooden addition was added onto the west corner of the building’s southern face. By 1942 the boiler house sat vacant and the boilers had been removed.
data.audioDescription: The #4 Boiler House is located southwest of the #2 Shaft House. The building still has its sloped north and south faces still standing along with most of the western wall. Bases of two chimneys on the north and the south of the building are also standing. The building is made from black poor-rock with evident grey mortar lines. Window frames on the north face of the building can be seen to have brick arches above them and some of the wooden sills remain. An arched doorway with brick top can also be seen on the north face. Holes where four windows would have set can be seen on the western face of the building.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins

images.altText: Spring scene of poor-rock building foundation.
images.title: Quincy #4 Shafthouse Ruins
images.caption: The Quincy Mine #4 Shafthouse ruins.

data.bodyText: Once a productive shaft for Quincy, the #4 plunged thousands of feet into the ground. The house itself was a 50-foot tall wooden building with a wire running southeast to the engine house. Today all that remains is the poor-rock foundation of the shafthouse. The building that used to cover the shaft allowed for some initial sorting of the ore coming from underground.
data.audioDescription: The Number Four Shaft Rock House is located west of the Number Four Engine House. Almost all the original structure is gone. What remains is a square poor-rock foundation with clear grey grout lines. The center of the structure has filled with dirt and now grows small shrubs and grass.

data.title: Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
data.listingDescription: The Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House was not only an engineering marvel, but also a company showpiece.

images.altText: tall three-story brick building with six tall rectangular windows
images.title: Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House
images.caption: The Quincy Mine 1918 Hoist House.

data.bodyText: Years into the mining decline, Quincy Mine flouted its optimism for the future by investing over $300,000 to house the world's largest steam hoist. The building to house the hoist is an extravagant structure is made of reinforced concrete with a brick veneer. Finishing touches include a green glazed tile roof, which has been removed, white tile interior, and brass railings. Recent rehabilitation includes exterior concrete repair and structural stabilization.
data.audioDescription: The Quincy Mining Company built the Quincy Hoist building as a visual showpiece on the landscape and in its interior. Located approximately 500 feet east of the #2 Shaft-rockhouse, the large three story brick building dwarfs all other nearby structures, including the former hoist house directly next to it on the south side. This impressive building is made from reinforced concrete with a brick veneer. Multiple windows allow natural light in. A series of tall metal pulley stands once stood between the hoist house and the shaft-rockhouse but today only two remain near the shaft-rockhouse. Just east of the hoist house is a long concrete trough, now overgrown with vegetation, used to cool and condense exhausted steam.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins
data.listingDescription: The remains of a Quincy locker room, otherwise known as the "Dry."

images.altText: interpretive wayside is next to a gravel path with a long ruin foundation in the background
images.title: Quincy Dryhouse Ruins
images.caption: The Quincy Dryhouse

data.bodyText: The Quincy Mine provided dryhouses where miners could change into work clothes at the beginning of a shift and back into home clothes at the end of the day. At the end of shift, miners could wash up, while work clothing was hung to dry. You may notice different colors of mortar, which may indicate previous preservation efforts. This dryhouse was a two-story structure made from poor-rock.
data.audioDescription: The hard packed gravel pathway ends with a large rectangular rock ruin to the south and a 3 foot high rectangular wayside to the east. The ruin is of a foundation of the former Quincy Mine Dryhouse and is made of black and dark gray poor rock that came from the Quincy Mine. The pathway goes to the top edge of the foundation which extends down about 5 feet. The foundation is approximately 30 feet wide by 60 feet long and stands 12 feet tall.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy & Torch Lake RR Water Tower

images.altText: Winter scene of white building with large wood beams underneath and wooden stairs leading to a door.
images.title: Quincy RR Water Tower
images.caption: The Quincy and Torch Lake Railroad water tower.

data.bodyText: Locomotives on the Quincy & Torch Lake railroad ran on steam, which required a water source. This stop, located next to the locomotive house and car repairing shop, was used to replenish the train’s water supplies. Due to the steep slope of the ground in this location the water tower sits on large wooden scaffolding. Recent conservation work on the building finished in 2019 which updated its exterior and preserved it for future generations.
data.audioDescription: The water tower is located on the north side of Round House Road, east of its intersection with Kowsit Lats Road. This small building is rectangular in shape with a steep pitched roof clad in asphalt shingles. The water tower sits on a steep hill so prominent wooden beam scaffolding can be seen supporting the structure. The western face of the building has a set of wooden stairs leading to the entrance and a single pained window. The south face of the building has a pipe leading from its base. A sign just to the south of the building reads “water tower.”

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Quincy Mining Company National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Russell Snowplow
data.listingDescription: Long, harsh winters were no match for the mighty C&H Mining Company.

images.altText: black and orange snow plow train on old rail tracks
images.title: Russell Snowplow
images.caption: The Russell Snowplow

data.bodyText: With over 200 inches of annual snowfall, keeping the rail lines open was an endless but necessary task. Without its own power, a steam locomotive "pushed" the snowplow to clear rail lines. Nearby, you may see evidence of historic railways once used to carry people, supplies, or equipment.
data.audioDescription: Sitting on old rail train tracks, the black and orange C&H Russell Snowplow was used to clear tracks of snow for the Calumet and Hecla Mining Company. The snowplow is constructed primarily of wood and is composed of a 28 foot front truck attached to a 16 foot back truck. The back truck resembles a conventional boxcar with small window openings and built in storage compartments. The front truck is comprised of a pilot's house behind a large double curved wood plow resembling the prow of a ship. This large v-plow has a metal blade just above the tracks. Two large retractable steel plow extensions are located to either side of the pilot's house which extend out to cut snow banks back along the track. The snowplow was designed to be positioned in front of a steam locomotive and pushed from behind to clear drifted snow.

quickFacts.value: Contributing Structure to the Calumet National Historic Landmark District
quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy 1894 Hoist House

images.altText: Winter scene of red and white Jacobsville sandstone two story building.
images.title: Quincy 1894 Hoist
images.caption: The Quincy Mine 1894 Hoist House.

data.bodyText: This hoist house was the 3rd in succession to serve the #2 shaft. The building is a 22-foot tall single story made from rough red and white Jacobsville sandstone with clean cut blocks to highlight the buildings corners and sides of windows and doors. Decorative red-brick arches can be seen above the windows and doors. Long since removed, the hoist inside raised copper rock and moved men to and from their worksites underground. The building and museum inside are now part of the Quincy Mine paid tour.
data.audioDescription: The 1894 Hoist House is located just south of the 1918 Number 2 Hoist House. The 1894 building is constructed of red and white Jacobsville sandstone with lighter blocks detailing the corners of the building and the sides of windows and doors. Redbrick arches were used to highlight the top of the windows. The western and eastern faces of the second story, along with the roof, are now made from silver-colored corrugated metal. The roofline slopes up steeply from the northern and southern faces of the building to a single ridgeline at the top, which runs east/west. The entrance to the building is located on the western face of the building. A concrete stair leads to a single-person door on the left face and a second entrance is also on the right side. A pair of double pained windows sit in the center of this face on the first story between the entrances. Four rectangular windows are spaced evenly across the second story face. The southern face of the building has eight rectangular double pained windows spaced evenly apart.

quickFacts.name: Significance

data.title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
data.listingDescription: The parking area for the Quincy Mine Dryhouse ruins.

images.altText: small parking area in wooded area with accessible picnic table and rock outcroppings
images.title: Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins Parking
images.caption: The parking area at the Quincy Mine Dryhouse Ruins

data.bodyText: The parking area for the Quincy Dryhouse Ruins has two trailheads. One leads to the dryhouse and one to an overview of the historic Quincy landscape. A picnic table is available for use. Nearby rock outcroppings show evidence of glaciation.
data.audioDescription: A single lane gravel road leads to a small parking area that has room enough for three vehicles. The parking area has a mixed hardwood forest to the west and an ADA accessible (I think) picnic table to the side of the parking lot. To the east, a small three foot wide hard packed gravel trail leads through tall grasses and former house foundation ruins to an overlook. Beyond the overlook, expansive views of the former Quincy Mining Company property, Portage Canal, and the Huron Mountains in the far distance can be seen.

data.title: Sand Storage
data.listingDescription: Sand was essential in the casting process.

images.altText: Winter scene of concrete building with boarded windows and doors.
images.title: C&H Sand Storage
images.caption: The Calumet & Hecla Sand Storage Warehouse.

data.bodyText: Calumet and Hecla’s sand storage building is located next to its pattern and foundry facilities. Sand was used in the foundry for casting tools and parts. A large supply was kept at this location. This building is a single-story structure of poured concrete and has a flat roof.
data.audioDescription: The sand storage building is located between the captain’s office and pattern storage warehouse. This long building is made from concrete and has a flat roof. The front face of the building has eight raised windows which have been boarded over with brown wood. Eight single person doors are set between the windows and are covered with red and brown painted wood. To the left of center of the building is a larger two-door access which is covered in red painted wood. There is a metal scaffolding set into the concrete surrounding this door and extending above the roof of the building.

data.title: Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k

images.altText: A trail sign next to a small, dirt trail, surrounded by rocks.
images.title: Access Trail at Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k
images.caption: Trail and scenery at Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k

data.bodyText:
Ever-changing Landscape 

This area wasn’t always a desert. As recent at 12,000 years ago, lush green vegetation covered the valleys and mountain slopes around you. Streams once fed a seasonal lake that is now the dry playa you just drove across. 

Changing Climate 

Pleistocene Epoch: Until 12,000 years ago, the climate in this region was much cooler and wetter. Thick soils anchored by lush vegetation covered rolling hills and slopes and water flowed through year-round streams. 

Present Day: At the end of the Pleistocene, the climate dried out and warmed up. The vegetation that was adapted to a wetter climate died, leaving behind bare slopes that are more vulnerable to erosion. Valley floors filled with sediment, creating the flat plains you see today. These plains are preserved because there isn't enough running water to erode them away. 

Changing Landscape 

Look for the following features to see evidence of an ever-changing landscape.  

Bajada: Find bajadas where alluvial fans merge to form a vast sediment slope at the mouth of canyons. 

Pediment: These sloping bedrock surfaces covered by gravel can be seen along the edges of mountains.  

Dry Wash: Washes transport sediment downhill. The smallest, lightest particles are carried farthest. Desert washes fill with rushing water after rain and monsoons. The washes in Joshua Tree spend most of the year dry.  

Playa: Streams carried sediment into a now dry lake. Clay and silt deposits are hundreds of feet deep here. 

Exploration Area 

Explore the desert surrounding you on foot. Notice the small details in the plants. Look for signs of animals. Take plenty of water with you. 

Glossary 

Alluvial fans: Alluvial comes from a Latin word, alluere meaning “to wash against”. Alluvial fans generally form where mountains meet the plains. A fast-running stream moving down a steep canyon can carry more sand, rocks, and pebbles, but when the water reaches the flat plains, it flows more slowly and can't carry the larger rocks and sand anymore. (Picture how fine silt settles out of a still lake, whereas a rushing river can push along sand, pebbles, and even large rocks.) These sediments accumulate in a fan shape at the mouth of canyons or washes. 

Bajada: A bajada is where many alluvial fans meet and converge.  

Pediment: A relatively flat or slightly concave surface of bedrock.

data.title: The Confederate Fort
data.listingDescription: The remains of the fort (Tour Stop #3) illustrate how the agricultural landscape of the 19th century was transformed into a military fortification. You can help us continue to preserve this historic resource by not walking or climbing on the fort walls or earthworks within the national battlefield.

images.altText: a view of the cabins
images.title: Inside the Confederate Fort Donelson
images.caption: A Summertime View of the Log Huts within the Fort

data.bodyText:
If you're at Tour Stop #3, you are inside the fortification. Earthen walls were constructed on the high ridges around the "bowl" or hollow. The park road was built through the fort walls; once you leave this area, you are driving or walking away from the fort toward the river.

The 15-acre fort was built between June-December 1861. Confederates built winter quarters, similar to the reproduction log hut visible from this point. This was a training camp for volunteers: they were mustered into Confederate regiments at this site, practiced their drills, and worked on the construction of the fort.

According to post-battle accounts, the huts were burned after the battle.

Weathering and erosion impacted the fortification since the Civil War. We urge you to protect these cultural resources by not walking on the fort wall.
data.audioDescription: The 15-acre fort sits upon a high point along the Cumberland River. The remains of the fort encircle a large "bowl" or hollow. The fort walls were built on top of the ridges surrounding this hollow. One reproduction log hut can be seen (and you may go inside) just adjacent to the parking area. It is believed that Confederates built winter huts similar to this during the winter of 1861-1862. Two wayside exhibits are accessed from this location: one in front of the log hut, and the other near a field gun across the park road. The walls of the fortification have eroded in the years after the 1862 battle. Signage directs visitors to stay off the fort walls to preserve the cultural resource. The walls have been sodded with grass and a few trees grow from the wall too.

data.title: Water Batteries
data.listingDescription: Two artillery positions were constructed on the banks of the river to provide formidable defenses against attack by the U.S. Navy. This site marks the location of the Valentine's Day battle between the ironclad gunboats and the Confederate artillerists. Today's views from the Cumberland River (Lake Barkley) offer outstanding views of the historic resources, and glimpses of wildlife and migratory birds.

images.altText: cannon looking at river
images.title: River Batteries on the Cumberland River
images.caption: 32-lb seacoastal cannon

data.bodyText:
Tour Stop #4 contains the site of the artillery batteries built by the Confederates for the defense of the Cumberland River. The upper gun battery has three guns: two 32-lb carronades and one rifled Columbiad. The lower battery features several 32-lb cannons and one smoothbore Columbiad.  

Rivers were strategically important for both armies. The Confederates chose this site to protect not only the waterway, but their supply base located in Nashville, TN.  

At this location, Confederate gunners exchanged fire with Union sailors aboard the City Series fleet of ironclad gunboats on February 14, 1862. If you walk in front of the gun battery emplacement at the Lower Gun Battery, you will find interpretive signs explaining the ironclads and a War Department plaque which describes the battle. Wayside intepretive exhibits are also located on the observation deck.
data.audioDescription: This historic area has both gun emplacements and cannons at two locations: the lower gun battery and the upper gun battery. The lower battery consists of seven 32-lb cannons and one columbiad. Two 32-lb cannons are resting on the grass near the park roadway. The upper gun battery has three guns, two 32-lb carronades and one rifled columbiad. Today, these features are separated by a parking area and limestone rock wall. The Cumberland River has been impounded by dams, thus it appears differently than it would have in 1862. The area across from this artillery battery is managed by the US Corps of Engineers. Depending on the season, you may see migratory waterfowl, duck blinds, flooded waters, or you may see crops such as soybeans or corn. The description of this area reflects the flow of the Cumberland River. The river flows north at this point; therefore, you pass by the Upper Gun battery first, and drive a little further, and you arrive at the Lower Gun battery. The Upper Gun battery can only be reached by trail. The trail is steep. The Lower Gun battery has an observation deck and one sidewalk. Exhibits may be found at both locations. Exhibits are also located on the observation deck. Walking around the gun emplacements at the Lower Gun battery, you will find interpretive exhibits and a War Department plaque which tell the story of the ironclad gunboats and 1862 battle.

data.title: Picnic Area - Long Jim Road
data.listingDescription: This picnic area, located near Mile Marker 248 near several small lookout points west of Grandview Point, has several picnic tables and is well shaded. Year-round ponderosa pines provide cover, while the spring and summer will some extra shade from a few local gamble oaks. There is, however, no view of Grand Canyon from here, nor are there restrooms.

images.altText: A wood and metal picnic table sits in the shade of pine trees.
images.title: Long Jim Road Picnic Area
images.caption: One of the quietest and shadiest spots for a picnic along Desert View Drive.

data.bodyText: This picnic area, located near Mile Marker 248 on the north side of SR 64 (Desert View Drive), has several picnic tables and is well shaded. Ponderosa pines provide year-round cover, while spring and summer feature even more shade from a few local gamble oaks. There is, however, unfortunately no view of Grand Canyon from here, nor are there restrooms.

data.title: ESCAPE to Colorado National Monument Stop 1
data.listingDescription: This is the first stop of the ESCAPE to Colorado National Monument self-guided experience.

images.altText: Crushed gravel path. Shrubs and trees are along either side of the path. View of a geologic features
images.title: Stop on the Alcove Nature Trail
images.caption: Scenic stop on the Alcove Nature Trail

data.bodyText:
This is the first stop along the ESCAPE to Colorado National Monument experience. The purpose of this activity is to calm and focus the mind to prepare for the coming activities. This activity focuses on a breathing exercise and meditation. You may listen to the audio portion for a guided meditation or read the self-guided meditation below. Once the activity is complete, you can answer the clue to release the first code word to advance your ESCAPE.

Self-Guided Meditation

Set a timer for 1 to 2 minutes. Find a comfortable position either seated or standing. Breathe in for four counts, hold for four counts, breathe out for four counts, and hold for four counts. This is called "square-breathing." You can imagine a square as you follow this cycle of breath until the timer goes off. If you feel comfortable, lower or close your eyes. Ready yourself, set your timer, and focus on your breath.

First Code Clue

Clue: In this exercise we focused on this six-letter word to calm and focus our minds.   

Write down the word and save it for later. If you are in a group, consider designating a “code keeper” to keep track of the code-words.  

Now that you have your word, move to “ESCAPE to Colorado National Monument Stop 2” to continue.

Want more?

If you enjoyed that activity and would like a moment to reflect, write down a few words that come to mind following the breathing exercise. How did it feel? What were you thinking about? If you are participating on the tour with others, consider sharing your reflections with a buddy.
data.audioDescription: On either side of the crushed gravel path are shrubs and trees. The soils also contain organisms. The soils are red, orange and brown in color. In the background is a view of geologic features including monoliths, mesas and hills.

Friendly staff, Civil War exhibits, the Passport to Your Parks stamps, Junior Ranger Handbooks, and a gift shop are available. One handicapped accessible restroom is located here. The Education Pavilion nearby is also stocked with information and Junior Ranger Handbooks.

data.title: Magnolia Mobil Gas Station
data.listingDescription: The historic Magnolia Mobil Gas Station at the southeast corner of South Park Street/West Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and across the street from Central High School’s campus played an important role in the 1957 desegregation crisis. This service station was one of the few businesses in the immediate neighborhood which had a pay telephone on site, so by default it served as the media headquarters for newspaper journalists, radio correspondents and television reporters.

images.altText: The historic Magnolia Mobil Gas Station, the de facto media headquarters during the 1957 crisis.
images.title: Magnolia Mobil Gas Station
images.caption: The historic Magnolia Mobil Gas Station, the de facto media headquarters during the 1957 crisis.

relatedParks.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Little Rock Central High School

tags: little rock central high school national historic site
data.bodyText:
“What Is Significant About the Gas Station?” 

Visitors to the site often are curious about the restored gas station and how it relates to the stories of Central High School. The Magnolia Mobil service station located at the corner of Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive and Park Street was built in the 1920s, about the same time that Little Rock Central High School was built. Throughout the years, the building has served as a gas station, a hangout for students, a temporary “office” for reporters during the desegregation crisis, storage for a wholesale florist business, and a National Historic Site visitor center. 

The History of the Gas Station 

This service station was built for the Magnolia Petroleum Company of Texas in the 1920s. Called the “Southwest” model, this station in Little Rock was identical to many others throughout Texas and Arkansas. The Magnolia Petroleum Company was one of many regional oil companies owned by Magnolia Oil Corporation. Founded as Vacuum Oil Company of Rochester, New York by Matthew Ewing and Hirman Everest in 1866, the company became a subsidiary of John D. Rockefeller’s Standard Oil Corporation of Ohio in 1879 and later a part of the Standard Oil Trust. In response to a 1911 Supreme Court decree against monopolies, the Standard Oil Group was broken into thirty-four companies. One of the successor companies, Standard Oil Company of New York (SOCONY), acquired full interest in the Magnolia Petroleum Company of Texas and some other regional oil companies before merging with the Vacuum Oil Company (another member of the Standard Oil Group) in 1931. 

As Socony-Vacuum the company led the way in pioneering lubricants and new energy sources. The name changed to Socony Mobil Oil Company in 1955, Mobil Oil Corporation in 1966, and Mobil Corporation in 1976. In the late 1950s, the station featured both Mobil and Magnolia signs to capitalize on regional and national brand identification. The station was in operation into the 1980s, when it closed and the building was acquired by the wholesale florist that was once located across the street. The company used it for storage until 1996, when Central High Museum, Inc., a nonprofit organization, purchased the property to use as a visitor center. The Mobil Foundation assisted in restoring the exterior of the station to its 1957 appearance. Mobil’s corporate archives supplied the architects with the original specifications for the vintage signage, the paint scheme, and the gas pumps. The visitor center opened in September 1997 for the 40th anniversary of the desegregation events at the school. 

In November 1998, President Clinton signed legislation designating Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site as a unit of the National Park Service. Central High Museum, Inc. donated the property to the National Park Service; the station served as the interim visitor center until September 2007 when the new permanent center opened on the 50th Anniversary of Central High's integration. 


During the 1957-58 School Year 

The service station was one of the few businesses in the immediate neighborhood and had a pay telephone on site. During the early days of the desegregation crisis, when reporters from all over the state, nation, and world converged on Little Rock, many phoned in their reports from the station. The press included a number of local and international reporters from magazines and newspapers such as The New York Times, Life, Look, Arkansas Gazette, Arkansas Democrat, Arkansas State Press, Der Spiegel (a German Periodical), Chicago Defender, and Baltimore Afro-American. 

In the 1950s, television was entering mainstream America as a medium for news, and the events in Little Rock were among the first major news events to be televised. Reporters representing the major networks featured live footage of the events as Arkansas National Guard troops, on orders of the governor, kept nine African American teenagers out of the school. 

“...the world media took a moral stand on Little Rock and they were horrified...there was so much media coverage, even though we knew [the people in the crowd] were crazy we also knew that they would have to be really crazy to kill one of us in public.”
Minnijean Brown Trickey, Little Rock Nine
data.audioDescription: The Magnolia Mobil Station is located across W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive from the park visitor center. The one-story white stucco structure with terracotta barrel tile roofing features three Mobil gas pumps beneath the service station's pull-through. Two former service bays are at the left side of the station with "Mobilgas" and "Mobilubrication" in lettering above the left and right doors, respectively. Above the main entrance door is a "Public Telephone" plaque. On the northwest corner of the station is a large metal Mobil sign mounted above the street corner. The west side of the building is bounded by grass and sidewalks leading to a side door and former location of the station's restrooms. The east side of the station is bounded by a parking lot with 7 parking spaces and 1 accessible parking space. The north side of the station has ballasts to keep vehicle traffic from entering on to the station grounds and is bordered by a sidewalk that shifts to a driveway apron on W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive. Today, the building serves as offices and storage space for the park's facilities/maintenance department and is not open to the public.

data.title: Native Shrublands
data.listingDescription: Stop 5 along the Hosmer Grove Nature Trail.

images.altText: a bench sits off the trail among a native shrubland with 360 views
images.title: Bench in a Native Shrubland
images.caption: This is a great spot to soak in the diversity of landscapes that surround you.

data.bodyText:
At this location you are near the park’s northern boundary looking down towards the ocean. This native shrubland is a remnant of the plants and trees that once blanketed every side of Haleakalā. Long before humans ever set foot upon the Hawaiian archipelago millions of years ago, native plants, insects, and birds arrived on these slopes through wind, water, and wings.
They built a pilina (interconnection) into a tight diversity of life that’s dependent on each other. Along this stretch of trail look for plant identification signs pointing out different shrubs.

Many of these plants serve in critical roles to provide food and homes for other endemic and endangered species, including the nēnē (Hawaiian goose). Berries from the shrubs of ʻōhelo, kukaenene, and pukiawe provide key food sources. Shrubland foliage is also critical to the geese for nesting season. Yellow flowers of the māmane tree provide nectar for native ʻiʻiwi honeycreepers. Notice how an ‘iʻiwi’s beak fits perfectly into the curve of a māmane bloom. Please give all wildlife space, never approach or feed them, and drive cautiously along park roadways.

Hosmer Grove is a stark contrast to a native shrubland around you, what are some of the differences you observe? Curiosity continues through ongoing studies on Hosmer's forested plots, giving researchers a chance to see how the introduced tree species cohabitate with native birds, insects, and their affect on native vegatation.
data.audioDescription: A bench sits at the top of the trail with a 360 panaromic view. Visible from this point is a non-native timber tree stand, the Pacific Ocean, the west Maui mountains/Mauna Kahalewai, and surrounding native shrubland plants.

data.title: Sculpture: Island Fox
data.listingDescription: Inspired by the unique wildlife of Channel Islands National Park, BiJian Fan's 3D kinetic, PVC sculptures combine science and art to educate and engage visitors to protect the park.

images.altText: The island fox is curled up in a tight ball on the ground as its bushy tail wraps around its body. T
images.title: Sculpture: Island Fox
images.caption: Sculpture: Island Fox

data.bodyText:
Inspired by the unique wildlife of Channel Islands National Park, BiJian Fan's 3D kinetic, PVC sculptures combine science and art to educate and engage visitors to protect the park.

Garden Art
Inspired by the unique wildlife of Channel Islands National Park, BiJian Fan's sculptures combine science and art to educate and engage visitors to protect the park.

BiJian was born in Beijing, China, where he learned paper art from his grandmother. Today, BiJian resides in Camarillo and still creates paper sculptures, but has also expanded to other materials.

In this exhibit, BiJian artistically transformed PVC into 3D kinetic sculptures of a pygmy mammoth, island fox, bald eagle, and other island species.

BiJian's artwork has exhibited internationally and earned numerous recognitions.


Island Fox Natural History
 

Scientific Name

Urocyon littoralis

Introduction

The island fox only lives on six of the eight Channel Islands off the coast of southern California--they are found nowhere else on Earth. Each island population is recognized as a separate endemic or unique subspecies.

The island fox, a descendant of the mainland gray fox, is the largest of the Channel Islands' native mammals, but one of the smallest canid species in the world.

Although foxes have always existed at low population sizes, four island fox subspecies underwent catastrophic declines in the 1990s. On San Miguel, Santa Rosa and Santa Cruz Islands at Channel Islands National Park, the decline was attributed to predation by golden eagles. The presence of non-native ungulates as a food source in addition to the DDT-caused decline of bald eagles, a natural competitor, facilitated the establishment of golden eagles as resident breeders on the islands. By 2000, predation on island foxes resulted in population declines to 15 individuals on San Miguel and Santa Rosa Islands, and less than 80 on Santa Cruz Island. In 2004, each of the park's island fox subspecies were federally listed as endangered.

In 1999, Channel Islands National Park began an island fox recovery program that included captive breeding and reintroduction of foxes, removal of resident golden eagles, re-establishment of bald eagles, and removal of non-native ungulates. This coordinated, organized and highly focused strategy was able to reverse the certain extinction of an endangered population. Today, the population has recovered within the park. Population trend and annual survival are currently monitored to ensure that recovery continues and future threats to the park's island fox subspecies are identified.

Quick and Cool Facts

  • It is the only carnivore unique to California.
  • Although the island fox is one of the smallest canids in the world, it is the largest native terrestrial mammal on the Channel Islands.
  • The island fox is one-third smaller than its mainland ancestor, the gray fox. At 12 to 13 inches in height and 4 to 5 pounds, the island fox is about the size of a housecat.
  • Some individuals have been known to live up to 15 years.
  • Unlike nocturnal gray foxes, which hunt exclusively at night to avoid predators, island foxes have no natural predators, allowing them to be active duringdaylight hours with peaks in activity occurring at dusk and dawn.
  • Visually, island foxes show signs of dominance or submission through facial expressions and body posture.
  • They communicate by barking and sometimes growling.
  • Their keen sense of smell plays an important role in the marking of territories. Island foxes are known to scent-mark their territories with a few drops of urine and tend to concentrate scats in particular areas, often conspicuously positioned on well-traveled paths.

Appearance

The island fox is one third smaller than its mainland ancestor the gray fox. Environmental and ecological factors such as overcrowding, reduction in predators, food limitations, and genetic variations could have contributed to the natural selection for a smaller size.

The island fox has similar markings to the gray fox. They have gray coloring on the back, rust coloring on the sides,and white underneath. The face has a distinctive black, white, and rufous-colored patterns.

On each of the six islands, a different subspecies occurs, distinguished by both genetic and physical differences. For example, San Miguel Island foxes have shorter tails, due to one less tail vertebra, and longer noses than the other island foxes.

Range

The island fox is found on six of the islands in the Southern California bight, including the three largest islands in the Channel Islands National Park (Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa and San Miguel islands). The other three islands which island foxes inhabit San Nicolas and San Clemente, owned by the US Navy, and popular Santa Catalina Island, which in large part is managed by the Catalina Island Conservancy.

Older research on the island fox dated them back on the northern Channel Islands to 10,400 to 16,000 years ago. Yet, geologists believe the northern Channel Islands were never connected to the mainland. The most plausible and accepted theory for foxes crossing the water barrier of the Santa Barbara Channel is one of "rafting." During the last ice age, 10-20,000 years ago, ocean levels were up to 400 feet lower than today's. The channel between the islands and mainland narrowed, perhaps to just four to five miles across. The northern islands became one large island we call Santarosae. The gray fox could have rafted on debris propelled by storms and/or currents. As the climate warmed and the ocean levels began to rise, Santarosae became the islands of Anacapa, Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, and San Miguel. Due to the lack of a fresh water source, the foxes did not persist on Anacapa, but the other three islands had suitable habitat for foxes.

Recent archeological work, however, only dates the oldest island fox fossil at about 6,000 years before present, which is several thousand years after native people populated the island. This raises the possibility that gray foxes were brought to the islands by humans, and rapidly evolved into a smaller, separate species after that.

Island foxes brought to the southern Channel Islands of Santa Catalina, San Nicolas, and San Clemente by the Chumash native people who traded with the Gabrielino people of the southern islands. The Chumash considered the fox to be a sacred animal--a pet of the sun, and possibly a dream helper. The island Chumash performed a fox dance and probably used the pelts of foxes to make articles like arrow quivers, capes, and headdresses.

Habitat

The climate of the California Channel Islands is semi-arid, and though rainfall amounts differ among islands the average rainfall across all islands is less than six inches per year. The native island vegetation is mostly coastal scrub, but these habitats have been heavily modified by the effects of introduced grazing animals and other human impacts. The northern islands (San Miguel, Santa Rosa and Santa Cruz) have significant areas dominated by non-native plant species, such as annual grasses and iceplant, whereas the southern islands (Santa Catalina, San Clemente and San Nicolas) have greater development impacts such as the naval bases and the town of Avalon. The larger islands (Santa Cruz, Santa Catalina, and San Clemente) also have perennial streams that support riparian vegetation and tree species. Foxes are found in most of these habitats on these islands, but they prefer shrubby or wooded areas such as chaparral, coastal scrub and oak woodlands.

Island foxes give birth to their young in simple dens, which are usually not excavated by the foxes themselves. By two months of age, young spend most of the day outside the den and will remain with their parents throughout the summer. Some pups disperse away from their natal territories by winter, although others may stay on their natal territories into their second year.

Feeding

Island fox diets vary based upon food item diversity of the individual islands. On San Rosa Island, where food item diversity is high, deer mice, Jerusalem crickets, beetles, and earwigs are the preferred food. On other Channel Islands, diets include plant items such as fruits from cactus, manzanita, saltbushes and seafigs, as well as insects and deer mice when they are present. Occasionally, foxes forage along the shoreline for crabs and other marine invertebrates.

Reproduction

Island foxes are generally monogamous (mate for life), and breed only once a year. Pairs are seen together frequently beginning in January, and mating takes place in late February to early March. The gestation period is thought to be similar to the gray fox, which is around 52 days, and pups are born from late April through early May. Litter size ranges from one to as many as five pups, but two or three is considered average. Born in the protection of a den, pups are blind and helpless with short dark brown hair at birth. They emerge from the den at about one month of age, much furrier but still considerably darker than adults. They begin to resemble their parents by late summer.

It is believed that island fox pups undergo a period of extended parental care. In a recent study of island foxes, scientists found adults and pups in the same trap on 22 occasions. In 24 traps containing only pups, they found killed mice and other prey items outside the traps, apparently left by the parents for their young. As with most wild canids, males play an important role in the rearing of young.

Conservation Status

The island fox, which only a short time ago was on the brink of extinction, provides an instructive example of how a coordinated, organized and highly focused strategy was able to reverse the certain extinction of an endangered population. Additional information about the strategies developed and implemented to reverse this situation may be found at Island Fox Conservation.

Due to these successful efforts, the IUCN Red List of Endangered Species now lists the island fox as near threatened.

Additional Information

  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/22781/0
  • http://www.arkive.org/island-fox/urocyon-littoralis/
  • http://islandfox.org/pdfs/foxfactsheet2.pdf
  • http://www.arkive.org/island-fox/urocyon-littoralis/
  • http://www.islandfox.org
  • http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/22781/0
  • http://www2.ucsc.edu/scpbrg/goeachannel.htm
data.audioDescription: The island fox is curled up in a tight ball on the ground as its bushy tail wraps around its body. The fox's dog-like face emphasizes long ears and a pointed snout. Tiny hole punch designs accent the ears and outline the eyes and nose.
